story: Rashida Tlaib is set to become the first Muslim woman in CongressMore women than ever will contest November's mid-term elections with record numbers winning party nominations for America's highest offices.After primary races in four states on Tuesday, there are around 182 female nominees for the House of Representatives and 11 women named as candidates for state governors. The results in Kansas, Michigan, Missouri and Washington mean female candidates have now broken records for gubernatorial and House nominations.Victories for Democrats Gretchen Whitmer in Michigan and Laura Kelly in Kansas mean 11 states will have women on the ballot in governorship races - one more than the previous 1994 record.Ms Whitmer, who beat Abdul El-Sayed - a physician hoping to become America's first Muslim governor - is leading an all-women ticket for the Democrats at state level in Michigan.Governors are the state's highest executives and have control over huge spending budgets.At least 182 female major party nominees will run for the House of Representatives, Congress' lower chamber, beating the record of 167 from 2016. A record number of women have also run for the Senate this year, with 42 women -  24 Democrats and 18 Republicans - registering to be candidates as of June 1, according to figures from the Center for American Women and Politics (CAWP).One candidate -  Rashida Tlaib - is certain to become the first Muslim woman in Congress.  Ms Tlaib won the Democratic nomination and will not be opposed by the Republicans in November's election. She will also be the first Palestinian-American congresswoman.Sharice Davids won a tightly fought Democratic primary in Kansas to becoming the state’s first Native American and gay nominee for Congress.Sharice Davids became the state&#39s first Native American and gay nominee for Congress after prevailing in a close six-candidate Democratic primary TuesdayThere will be two all-female races in Washington state. Democrat Lisa Brown faces Cathy McMorris Rodgers for a seat in the House, while Republican Susan Hutchison will take on incumbent Senator Maria Cantwell.Earlier this year, Stacey Abrams made headlines as she became the Democratic candidate for Georgia's governorship with  75 per cent of the vote in the Democratic primary.  If she wins on November 6, Ms Abrams will be the state's first black female governor.Ms Abrams has already made history as both the first black candidate and the first woman to be nominated by a major party in the southern state. Stacey Abrams smiles after winning the Democratic nominationHowever the 44-year-old lawyer faces a tough battle - a Democrat has not been elected governor in the deeply conservative state since 2003.Ms Abrams, who won  in Tuesday's Democratic primary, said:  “We are writing the next chapter of Georgia’s history, where no one is unseen, no one is unheard and no one is uninspired”.Three other southern states -  Kentucky, Arkansas and Texas - also elected female nominees in their May Democratic primaries.Girl, nine, dies after being struck by rock fall in Staithes, North Yorkshire US imposes sanctions on Russia over Salisbury spy poisoningComment: The burka looks ridiculous, and those who defend it do Muslim women like me no favoursComment: The harrying of British veterans over Bloody Sunday is macabre and unfair Burkas are like wearing a crucifix and should be defended, says Ruth Davidson, as Boris row escalatesHomeless people wearing barcodes to accept cashless paymentsCalais migrant aid groups claim Britons are being &#39singled out&#39 with police intimidationEdinburgh and Glasgow universities allocate all remaining Scottish clearing places to poor applicantsEaster Island seeks return of &#39stolen&#39 Moai statue from the British MuseumGermany agrees deal with Spain to return migrants who registered there firstMissing child found dead at squalid New Mexico hideoutComment: With waiting times at an all-time high, we must make it easier to recruit GPs from abroadPrincess Beatrice turns 30: A look at how her fashion has evolvedChris Collins: Republican Congressman charged with insider trading vows to clear his nameAir-to-air missile &#39accidentally fired&#39 by Spanish Typhoon jet over EstoniaComment: Don&#39t trust the &#39natural birth&#39 myth. story: Created with Sketch.Actress spoke at length about her storied career, experiences with sexism, and what she thought of the 'Friends' castClick to followThe Independent CultureKathleen Turner calls Friends cast 'unwelcoming and cliquey' in frank interview about her Hollywood careerKathleen Turner has criticised the way she was treated during her time on the hit sitcom&nbspFriends.&nbspThere are several talking points from the interview, including her refusal to be typecast, which saw her take aim at one unnamed actress for playing the same role for 20 years.&nbspFirst look at Margot Robbie as Sharon Tate in new Tarantino filmJohnny Depp film pulled from cinemas weeks before releaseMatthew Perry 'rushed to hospital' after suffering ruptured bowelShe even looks pretty much the same, she said. She's probably one of the richest women out there, but I would shoot myself if I were like that, only giving people what they expect.The internet has been busy trying to work out who she was talking about, with many calling it the 'You're So Vain' of celebrity interviews. So far the guesses include Reese Witherspoon, Sandra Bullock, Julia Roberts and Jennifer Aniston.&nbsp25 new films to look out for in 2018 that aren't sequelsCast: Ethan Hawke, Amanda Seyfried, Cedric the Entertainer825 The Miseducation of Cameron Post1025 City of Lies1325 The House with a Clock in Its Walls1625 Bad Times at the El Royale2525 Holmes and WatsonCast: Ethan Hawke, Amanda Seyfried, Cedric the Entertainer825 The Miseducation of Cameron Post1025 City of Lies1325 The House with a Clock in Its Walls1625 Bad Times at the El Royale2525 Holmes and WatsonI remember I was wearing this difficult sequinned gown - and my high heels were absolutely killing me, she said. I found it odd that none of the actors thought to offer me a seat. Finally it was one of the older crew members that said: 'Get Miss Turner a chair.'The&nbspFriends&nbspactors were such a clique - but I don't think my experiences with them were unique, she continued. I think it was simply that they were such a tight little group that nobody from the outside mattered.Turner also spoke of her experience being a sexual target after starring in&nbspBody Heat,&nbspand recalled how actors Michael Douglas, Jack Nicholson and Warren Beatty had a competition for who would get me first... none of them did, by the way.&nbspI didn't like being thought of as a trophy, she added. There was an unspoken assumption that women were property to be claimed... assumptions like that are why I've never lived in Los Angeles. story: Created with Sketch.Former state representative describes victory as ‘happy chaos’Click to followThe Independent USRashida Tlaib: First Muslim woman to be elected to US Congress after winning Michigan Democratic primaryFormer Michigan state representative Rashida Tlaib will become the US’s first ever Muslim woman elected to Congress after she won a Democratic primary election to represent Michigan’s 13th district. Running in a crowded field of candidates vying to replace John Conyers Jr, who served from 1965&nbspuntil retirement last year following claims of sexual harassment, Ms Tlaib took 33.6 per cent of the vote following a strong grassroots campaign in which she raised over $1m (£780,000).There are no Republican candidates contesting the seat, so Ms Tlaib will enter Congress unopposed following a special election on 6 November&nbspwhen she will formally replace Mr Conyers.Trump-endorsed Kris Kobach in governor’s race that came down to wireMissouri primary election will decide fate of ‘Right to Work’ billEverything you need to know about Michigan’s upcoming primariesDiane Black, endorsed by Mike Pence, loses to Bill LeeHer nearest rival was Detroit Council president Brenda Jones, who despite wider name recognition and several prominent endorsements&nbsptook 28.5 per cent of the vote.Ms Tlaib, the daughter of two Palestinian immigrants, was born in Detroit in 1976, where her father had a job at the Ford motor company. She studied politics at Wayne State University, and then law, graduating in 2004. On Tuesday evening, she said her day had been filled with emotion and described it as “happy chaos” to&nbspThe Detroit News.“Especially meeting voters and talking to them, they are inspired,” she told the paper before the polls closed.“One resident said she’s happy for me and has already written. It’s been amazing to interact with families at polling locations. title: International Cat Day Britain left streets vet animal nature uk news
story: Igloo cannot stop crying  (Image: NC)Having been rescued by a leading animal charity, an appeal has gone out to cat lovers who want to give Igloo a reason to purr &mdash although her tears will never stop flowing.One year old Igloo was found wandering the streets of north west London without a microchip or collar to help trace her owners.Veterinary checks at the Mayhew Animal Home soon revealed why the little black cat looked as if she was constantly in tears.Mayhew Vet Dr Emma Robinson, explained how Igloo had arrived with mild conjunctivitis in both eyes but even after treatment she continued shedding tears.                Elderly cat FINALLY finds its way home after spending 13 YEARS                 Ten things you never knew about&hellip catsDr Robinson said: &ldquoWe suspected that this may be due to a blockage of the tear ducts, meaning that the tears do not drain from the eye as they normally would.&ldquoIf the tear ducts are blocked, the tears are unable to drain away and end up running down the face.&ldquoBlockage can be due to abnormalities of the ducts from birth or due to damage from a virus.&ldquoWe were able to flush the left tear duct under anaesthetic, allowing drainage from that duct.One year old Igloo was found wandering the streets of north west London (Image: NC)&ldquoUnfortunately the right tear duct is permanently altered meaning that she will always have a mild discharge from the right eye.&ldquoThis does not cause her discomfort, but just means the area around the eye needs to be cleaned and dried daily.As an appeal for a new home for Igloo went out on International Cat Day, the Mayhew Animal Home says for all her eye problems, she will put a smile on the face of any potential owner.Her foster mum Tessa said: &ldquoIgloo has been a joy to look after.Dr Emma Robinson, explained how Igloo had arrived with mild conjunctivitis in both eyes (Image: NC)&ldquoShe loves to play, scampering down the hallway to hide just out of sight, inviting me to follow for games with her ribbons, shoelaces and feathers.&ldquoShe is the sweetest friend and her clear happiness when she is feeling loved is a wonderful thing to share.&ldquoIgloo doesn&rsquot miaow, but she&rsquos very expressive with her variety of enchanting little noises.Anyone interested in adopting Igloo or any cats in Mayhew&rsquos care, should visit www.themayhew.org or call on 020 8962 8000.

title: brexit news theresa may chequers deal no deal brexit get britain out
story: The cross-party Get Britain Out grassroots campaign group will deliver a letter endorsed by an estimated 50,000 supporters.It is not known if Mrs May will be at home, and it is not usual for Prime Ministers to accept such petitions in person.But the group sees the event as a chance to underline the anger felt at the Chequers deal for continued close links with the European Union, which Mrs May agreed with her Cabinet.The group has compiled the names of the tens of thousands of people who got in touch online to confirm they agreed with a letter posted on its website by Get Britain Out director, Jayne Adye.                Verhofstadt&rsquos DEPUTY admits Brexit shows the EU has FAILEDMs Adye said a previous letter to Mrs May on the issue received only a holding reply from the PM's communications unit.The latest letter which Ms Adye says thousands more supporters have flocked to endorse, tells Mrs May that the vast majority of the public do not accept your proposed future relationship with the EU.The Government&rsquos White Paper does not deliver Brexit in any meaningful sense of the word.It is not what we voted for in 2016. It would not bring about any of the crucial benefits of leaving the EU.Brexit news: Theresa May is set to receive a petition signed by furious Brexiteers (Image: )Tens of thousands of members of the electorate are rallied behind us as signatories to these letters to you, demanding you uphold the wishes of the great British public when they were led into the EU referendum by David Cameron.Ms Adye adds that her hopes the resignations over the Chequers deal of Brexit Secretary David Davis and Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson might bring Mrs May to her senses were dashed by the Government's white paper detailing its proposals.Tonight Ms Adye said: Our grassroots supporters feel betrayed, forgotten, and let down by the current direction of UK-EU Brexit negotiations, which clearly do not reflect the mandate given by the EU referendum result.The Chequers proposal will keep us under European Court of Justice jurisdiction, limit our capacity to strike free trade deals, and keep us bound by the red tape of the Single Market.                &lsquoI GUARANTEE it!&rsquo City expert bets &pound3.6BN on UK negotiating free tradeBrexit news: Thousands of Brexiteers said they no longer believe Mrs May can deliver a good Brexit (Image: )The great British public clearly believe in this country and what we can do when standing on our own two feet. We deserve a political class with this same patriotic conviction.If Theresa May and most of those in her Remainer Cabinet are unwilling to implement the biggest political mandate in UK history, they should step aside and allow someone to take over with true conviction and insight into all the opportunities we have for our global future - instead of encouraging Project Fear Mark II.They simply do not have their heart and soul in Brexit for the British people.

story: Neither eurocrats nor member states have accepted Mrs May&rsquos request to add Brexit to the agenda for the summit in Salzburg on September 20.Downing Street insists Austrian leader Sebastian Kurz, who is hosting the summit, has agreed for Brexit to be at the top of the agenda.However, no such message has been heard from Austria, and EU Council chief Donald Tusk remains undecided.An EU ambassador said leaders would be unimpressed if the Prime Minister fails to present a fresh idea to the table.&nbsp                Brexit news: No-deal split will stop vital drugs from reaching the EU                Pound US dollar exchange: GBP down against USD on Brexit uncertaintyThey told the Sun: &ldquoThe suggestion was done by the British side. It has not been commented on by Mr Tusk nor by any other EU leader.&ldquoKurz has not accepted that at all or acknowledged it, he just took note of this wish by the British prime minister.&ldquoWe don&rsquot know what we should be discussing in Salzburg. We haven&rsquot got a clue because there&rsquos nothing on the table. It&rsquos not on the agenda.UK officials stand their ground and say Mr Kurz &ldquoconfirmed to Mrs May that Brexit would be added to the agenda after their meeting on July 27.The informal meeting next month could be a way for Mrs May to sell her Chequers plan vision directly to leaders.Follow Express for live updates7.20pm -&nbspSNP MSP James Dornan&nbsprips into Theresa May's brexit blueprint, brands cabinet ministers as 'nutters'Mrs May met with Scottish first minisger Nicola Sturgeon on Tuesday in Edinburgh, to sign off on a &pound1.2 billion funding boost for Scotland.But echoing Ms Sturgeon's views of a catastropic no-Deal scenario, Mr Dornan told Russia Today: &ldquoEveryone agreed on it until they left the room and started to backstab about it.The Chequers plan may well have been a better step than they had before but it was never going to last.&ldquoIt is about getting it through the system, it is about getting Westminster to support it. that cost &pound11,000Andy pardy, 28, quit his job and bought a camper van and is travelling across Europe spelling out the words using a GPS tracker.But critics have mocked Mr Pardy for having too much time on his hands - and blowing his savings account on the trip.Mr Pardy told The New European: &ldquoI had basically enough&hellip I had the deposit for a house.&ldquoAnd I was at the stage where it was like&hellip I wouldn&rsquot say I had a mid-life crisis, but I had to really think, OK, do I want to buy a house, be locked into a commitment whereby I have to stay in my job for the foreseeable future, or do I take that money and just do something like this? title: perseid meteor shower swift tuttle comet how to watch
story: Perseids meteor shower: Swift-Tuttle comet could DESTROY life on Earth (Image: )The Perseids meteor shower will peak this weekend between the night of Saturday, August 11, and the morning of Monday, August 13.While the people of Earth will be treated to a dazzling display of a meteor shower, the comet responsible for the shooting stars might not be as kind to us in the future.The 16-mile-wide Comet Swift-Tuttle is leaves behind a trail of meteors which cause the Perseids meteor shower.But there is a chance the huge space rock could strike Earth in the future and if it does, the power would be 30 times greater than the asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs.An impact like this would surely wipe out ALL life on Earth.                Perseids Meteor Shower 2018: When is shower peak? How to watch Pers...Experts warn that in the future, Jupiter, which the comet also passes, could gravitationally pull on it, changing Swift-Tuttle&rsquos direction and putting it on a collision course with our planet.Forbes&rsquo resident scientist Ethan Siegel wrote: &ldquoIf Swift-Tuttle were to strike Earth, it would release more than one billion megatons of energy: the energy equivalent of 20,000,000 hydrogen bombs exploding all at once.&lsquoWithout a doubt, the comet that gives rise to the Perseids is far and away the single most dangerous object known to humanity.&ldquoIt would mark the largest mass extinction our world has seen in hundreds of millions of years.However, we are safe for now.The next time Swift-Tuttle will be within a million miles of Earth will be August 5, 2126 and August 24, 2261.However, it is the passing in 4479 when we will not be 100 percent safe.Even then, there is only a one in a million chance it will hit Earth.Express Pictures brings you Earth's encounters with meteors captured from around the world.                     Caters News Agency1 of 37A meteor captured above the erupting Klyuchevskaya Sopka volcanoConditions this year are expected to be ideal thanks to the darkened New Moon keeping the skies dark thought the shower.The Perseids arrive each year in the night skies when the Earth passes through the cosmic trail of Comet Swift-Tuttle.The meteor shower always starts around mid-July and wraps towards the end of August, peaking about mid-way through.

title: Brexit news UK EU medicine supply chain AstraZeneca latest
story: Brexit news: Medicines giant warns EU could be deprived of vital drugs in no-deal scenario (Image: )The Cambridge-based drugs manufacturer said it would not be able to guarantee its supply of medicines to the Continent putting patients at risk.Bosses said its cancer, heart and lung drugs, which are made and quality-tested in the UK, would have to be evaluated twice to ensure they are allowed to cross the border after Brexit.AstraZeneca, one of the world's leading pharmaceutical firms, issued the stark warning to a Dutch government website designed to offer Brexit planning advice.Ad Antonisse, the company's Dutch external affairs director, said the company needs to prepare well for a no-deal Brexit, adding it is carry out tests in both the UK and EU as it prepares for the strongest Brexit scenario.He told the Brexit-loket website: If we do not prepare well for Brexit, patients in the EU may no longer be able to receive their medicines, just because production happens to happen in the UK.AstraZeneca is setting up a parallel operation in Sweden as part of its &pound40million post-Brexit preparations.With its EU base, the firm believes it can maintain the supply of medicines in both the UK and on the Continent in the event of a failure to agree of reciprocal regulations.Ann Marie Horan, of the Irish Pharmacies Union, called for drugs to be stockpiled to minimise any disruption in the medicines supply chain from Britain.                ECJ says suspect CANNOT use Brexit to avoid UK EU arrest warrant                EU has more lose than us with no-deal Brexit - EXPRESS COMMENTShe said: The UK is obviously the largest English-speaking country in the EU and 37 million patented packs of drugs go into the UK every month and 45 million come out. That is 1 billion per year.Six out of ten of our drugs are manufactured in the UK or else they&rsquore labelled in the UK with English-speaking inserts so anything that disrupts that supply chain is really scary.We as pharmacists are on the frontline so we are the people who will have to explain to our patients, &lsquoyou know we can&rsquot get your drug&rsquo, and that&rsquos such a horrible, horrible thought, added Ms HoranLast month, Health Secretary Matthew Hancock said officials were working with industry to prepare for a no-deal Brexit by stockpiling drugs, medical devices and supplies.He told the House of Common's Health Select Committee: We are working right across Government to ensure that the health sector and the industry are prepared and that people's health will be safeguarded in the event of a no-deal Brexit.This includes the chain of medical supplies, vaccines, medical devices, clinical consumables, blood products.And I have asked the department to work up options for stockpiling by industry. We are working with industry for the potential need for stockpiling in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

story: Economist Kit Juckes said that the possibility of a harder &lsquocliff-edge&rsquo Brexit with WTO rules was &ldquoan increase possibility but admitted that it was scary for the economy.Mr Juckes, the global strategist at Societe Generale told Bloomberg: &ldquoWe used to think a hard Brexit was a break which took us out of the single market and the customs union.&ldquoNow a hard Brexit is what we used to call a &lsquocliff edge&rsquo Brexit where we just leave with nothing back to WTO rules.&ldquoSo already what we are calling hard is a lot harder than what we were calling it a year ago.Brexit LIVE: Row erupts as EU says it may NOT discuss EU exit next ...Brexit news: May plotting to EXPLOIT Trump trade battle to secure deal&ldquoThat is an increase possibility and frankly, a relatively scary one for the economy.The cross-party Get Britain Out grassroots campaign group will deliver a letter endorsed by an estimated 50,000 supporters to Number 10 Downing Street on Wednesday.It is not known if Theresa May will be at home, and it is not usual for Prime Ministers to accept such petitions in person.But the group sees the event as a chance to underline the anger felt at the Chequers deal for continued close links with the European Union, which Mrs May agreed with her Cabinet.Economist says hard Brexit has become even harder in the last year (Image: Bloomberg &bull Getty)The group has compiled the names of the tens of thousands of people who got in touch online to confirm they agreed with a letter posted on its website by Get Britain Out director, Jayne Adye.The latest letter which Ms Adye says thousands more supporters have flocked to endorse, tells Mrs May that the vast majority of the public do not accept your proposed future relationship with the EU.The Government&rsquos White Paper does not deliver Brexit in any meaningful sense of the word.It is not what we voted for in 2016. It would not bring about any of the crucial benefits of leaving the EU.Tens of thousands of members of the electorate are rallied behind us as signatories to these letters to you, demanding you uphold the wishes of the great British public when they were led into the EU referendum by David Cameron.Mrs May held talks with the First Minister Nicola Sturgeon on Tuesday with the pair signing off the latest expansion of a &pound1.2billion funding boost for Scotland.Ms Sturgeon and Mrs May were both expected to discuss Brexit during their meeting on Tuesday.The First Minister has urged the Prime Minister not to engage in scare tactics as she claimed a no-deal Brexit would be catastrophic for the UK.

title: Thousands loos lost public toilet council funding uk news
story: There are now 39 per cent less public loos in the UK than there were in 1998 (Image: )The study by the British Toilet Association and Domestos found that the average council in the UK now operates just 15 public loos.It is estimated that in 1998 there were around 6,000 public loos across the UK, but more than 2,000 have since been closed down, leaving around 3,650 open now.With 65million people living in the UK, that works out at each toilet block serving around 17,800 Brits.The study, to launch a nationwide campaign called Use Our Loos - an initiative to increase the availability of conveniences in public places &ndash also found that 12 of the 266 councils which responded to the Freedom of Information requests did not provide any public toilets at all.                Council in crisis says it can&rsquot pay for care services                Fury as council approves traveller site EXPANSION A spokesman for the campaignThose included councils covering Bolsover, Milton Keynes, Northeast Derbyshire, Redditch, South Northamptonshire, North Kesteven, Wokingham, Cambridgeshire and Wakefield as well as East Renfrewshire in Scotland and Merthyr Tydfil and Newport in Wales.A spokesman for the campaign said: These closures, a result of tightening of local budgets, cause much more than inconvenience to some members of society, including the elderly, parents of young children and pregnant women, whose independence relies on the availability of public amenities.Use Our Loos will work with local cafes, restaurants, pubs and shops on UK high streets to open their loos to the public in the first national scheme of its kind.Members of the public can use the Great British Public Toilet Map or look out for the new Use Our Loos logo in shop windows to locate nearby participating businesses.The average council in the UK now operates just 15 public loos. (Image: )He added: Legally, UK councils are not required to provide public toilets, however, these have been a common part of the High Street for more than a century.In most cases, the reduction is a result of government budget cuts that mean many local authorities can no longer afford to maintain public toilets.Some local areas are without a single free-to-use public toilet.This presents a challenge for many but especially for those iniduals who rely upon more frequent access to a bathroom such as parents with young children and those with medical conditions.The spokesman added: Businesses that sign up to Use Our Loos can expect to benefit from their new open-door policy.                Council asked for &pound559 from Nairn mum for sandcastle competition                Council wants to rent out YOUR driveway for &pound5-a-week to make room on They will have the opportunity become more closely connected to their community by providing this service.Each participating establishment will be encouraged to have a Use Our Loos sticker on display, so the public can easily spot a business that is happy for people to use its toilets without necessarily being a customer.Members of the public can find participating toilets via the Great British Public Toilet Map, the most comprehensive list of publicly available loos in the UK.Started by the Helen Hamlyn Institute of Design at the Royal College of Art, the map pulls on open data and community generated data to plot 11,300 publicly available toilets across England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.Use Our Loos participating shops, cafes, pubs and restaurants will be added to this map. The public are also invited to urge their local businesses to join the scheme.Council budgets are to blame for the lack of public toilets (Image: )Raymond Martin, Director of the British Toilet Association, said: We know that councils are under immense pressure with their budgets and despite having no legal obligation to maintain these public facilities, they have continued to try to halt the rapid rate of decline.They are constantly looking at alternative ideas, such as inidual Community Toilet Schemes, to provide reasonable provision for their communities.Use our Loos is a community-oriented solution not about opening more public toilets but making more toilets public that already exist. Rebecca Light, of Unilever UK, said: We believe everyone deserves access to a clean, safe lavatory.In the UK the problem is locating a public toilet when we're out and about, in other countries the problem is far more serious.An estimated 2.3 billion people worldwide lack access to clean, safe sanitation while around 892 million don't have sanitation facilities at all.This comes with significant health risks, including diseases like diarrhoea, which kills one child every two minutes. From the UK to India, it's vital we change this - and quickly.

title: emmanuel macron french president popularity drops poll shows
story: The French centrist faced the biggest political crisis of his tenure after a video of his security chief beating up two protesters was revealed by the daily Le Monde last month.The poll, conducted by YouGov for the Huffington Post and the French television channel CNews, showed that Mr Macron&rsquos approval rating had fallen to 27 per cent, down five percentage points from June.The survey also marked the young centrist&rsquos lowest YouGov approval rating since he took power in May 2017.&nbspAt 62 per cent, Mr Macron&rsquos disapproval rating reached a record high, YouGov said, although the polling institute stressed that respondents had been asked to comment on &ldquothe president&rsquos actions, and not on his image.&nbsp                Brexit news: France should RELENT on hardline negotiating position Mr Macron&rsquos office came under fire last month after Alexandre Benalla, the former head of the president&rsquos&nbspsecurity detail, was caught on camera assaulting two May Day protesters while off duty and wearing a riot helmet and police tags.The video, which was released by the left-leaning daily Le Monde on July 18, sparked nationwide outrage, with opposition leaders accusing the government of failing to properly punish Mr Benalla or refer him promptly to judicial authorities.Mr Macron faced further criticism after he slammed the French media&rsquos coverage of the incident.He said: &ldquoWe have a press that is no longer pursuing the truth&hellip What I see is media power that wants to become judicial power.Emmanuel Macron's popularity is dwindling (Image: )Mr Benalla, 26, was sacked shortly after the video was made public and charged with gang violence and impersonating a police officer.However, another poll also published last week painted a more positive picture of Mr Macron&rsquos presidency in the wake of the Benalla scandal.The survey, conducted by Elabe for the newspaper Les Echos and Radio Classique, found that Mr Macron&rsquos popularity rating had climbed two percentage points in one month, with 36 per cent of respondents saying they trusted him to fix the country&rsquos problems.Sixty per cent of those polled said they &ldquodidn&rsquot trust him.&nbspThe poll asked respondents to comment on the president's actions not on his image (Image: getty)Eight out of 10 people, however, said they were &ldquoshocked by Mr Benalla&rsquos behaviour.Several French pollsters have since weighed in on Mr Macron&rsquos mixed bag poll results.Ifop&rsquos deputy chief Fr&eacuted&eacuteric Dabi said that the scandal had had a &ldquoreal impact but failed to dent public opinion while Jean-Daniel L&eacutevy of Harris Interactive likened the controversy to a &ldquoslow poison that could come back to haunt the Mr Macron in the future.The YouGov poll of 1,017 people was carried out online between July 25 and July 26 while the Elabe poll of 1,007 people was carried out online between July 31 and August 1.

title: karren brady switch off phone
story: Remember the days when a mobile phone was like a hulking great brick? Available only to the elite few who could afford them at first, they were designed purely to enable people to take a call while away from home.Fast forward a couple of decades and we are all glued to our devices, a nation of addicts.We are now so wedded to our smartphones that we check them every 12 minutes.The average Brit spends more than a day a week online, twice as long as ten years ago.This surge in time online is largely down to the rise of smartphones, which are now used by 78 per cent of the population compared with just 17 per cent in 2008.My personal bugbear is people who walk along the street in a slow zig-zag because they are glued to their phone.And there’s nothing worse than someone who interrupts a conversation to take a call or read a text.It surely can’t be a coincidence that, in the same week as this report was released, we hear about five-year-olds starting school unable to speak in sentences — partly, no doubt, down to parents plugging them into a screen rather than talking or reading to them.I’ve got a Blackberry, mainly because I like the keyboard. But I am probably as hooked on it as the next person.It’s an invaluable tool for anyone wanting to work flexibly. But I also do a fair amount of pointless surfing on it.I’m not into all forms of social media, but I am a bit of a news junkie and I’ll confess I also watch the odd funny YouTube film with my kids.Unfortunately, progress in technology has brought the idea that we “should” all be available 24/7.In fact, people are quite indignant if you don’t reply to an email within the hour — even if it’s sent at 4am.Being a conscientious type, the result for me if I’m not careful, is that if I wake up in the night I’ll check my emails and maybe even reply to a few before going back to sleep. Now that can’t be good for the old circadian rhythms.The other problem with everyone being always available and always “on” is that our FOMO — fear of missing out — has increased exponentially.We’re all terrified that if we’re offline for too long we won’t get to . . . what exactly? See photos of someone’s hashtag perfect holibobs with the famalam — and then feel like our life is rubbish by comparison?I use Twitter a bit but I avoid Facebook and Instagram, partly because I don’t want the possibility that the opinions and “likes” of people I don’t know may influence me more than my own values and views.And another problem with the prevalence of tech is that we don’t have any down time.All those previously blank moments — on the bus, waiting for our microwave meal to cook, lying in bed at night — have all become an opportunity to surf, tweet, and message. We are going to burn out if we aren’t careful.I always know when I’m really relaxed because I accidentally go out without my phone.Granted, it generally only happens when I’m on holiday.But now I know how close we are to becoming actual addicts, I feel like we should all build in some time away from our devices.After all, the more time we spend looking at a screen, the less time we spend looking at the world and engaging with other people.So maybe we should all take a moment to leave our phone at home, go for a walk, and switch from “on” to “off”.Isn’t that a liberating thought?I’M sure a fair few people felt a bit guilty reading about the Vogue interview with Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie this week.The sisters talk about how hard it is living in the public eye but also the criticism and mockery they face, often attacked for taking too many holidays.Who knows, perhaps some of that criticism is justified.But a lot of the comments they get are about their appearance and clothes – and that is where it crosses a line.No-one chooses the family into which they are born, and they are trying to make the best of the hand they’ve been given.They are trying to build careers and have a personal life while being in the public eye and that can’t be easy.I hope people realise that and give them a break.HAVING spent the past couple of decades getting annoyed at anyone who utters the words “Poor Jennifer Aniston”, this week, for the first time ever, I said them myself.You know why?Because the 49-year-old has been forced to publicly address, again, the tedious topic of why she hasn’t had a baby.She also alluded to something no woman should have to share with anyone they don’t want to, let alone the world – the fact she might be medically unable to procreate.Poor Jen. She can’t just get on with her very successful – and no doubt happy – life without being plagued by speculation.In the same interview she took the chance to spell it out: Just because she split from Justin Theroux doesn’t mean her life is over.She might even be happy to have finally got shot of him.“The misconceptions are ‘Jen can’t keep a man’,” she said. “And ‘Jen refuses to have a baby because she’s selfish and committed to her career.’ Or that I’m sad and heartbroken . . . first, with all due respect, I’m not heartbroken. And second, those are reckless assumptions.“No one knows what’s going on behind closed doors. No one considers how sensitive that might be for my partner and me. They don’t know what I’ve been through medically or emotionally.“There is a pressure on women to be mothers, and if they are not, then they’re deemed damaged goods. Maybe my purpose on this planet isn’t to procreate. Maybe I have other things I’m supposed to do.”So yes. Poor, poor Jen being under the world’s watchful and pitying eye all the time.Just to remind people. Jennifer Aniston is one of the world’s most successful stars.She has a big group of friends and a beautiful home, which she bought herself. She has dogs she adores, she’s funny, busy, and fulfilled.But all of that is worth nothing, of course. She doesn’t have kids.To anyone reading this who thinks women must have children to be fulfilled, please take note: Plenty of women don’t want to get married or have kids.Many other women want kids but can’t have them.And guess what? It’s none of our business.Here’s another way of looking at Jennifer’s life. She is lucky.She gets to please herself and hasn’t had to make any of the sacrifices that many of us make to become mothers.Also, George Clooney didn’t meet Amal until he was 51. Hugh Grant got married this year at 57 (after many failed relationships). Leonardo DiCaprio, 43, and Jude Law, 45, are still single and dating. Has anyone ever said: “Poor George/Hugh/Leonardo/Jude”?Of course they haven’t. So let’s stop saying it about Jennifer, too.I SO related to Carol Vorderman’s delight at being asked for proof of age when she bought some wine at M&ampS recently.When you’re young, being asked to prove your age, as the presenter, above, was is very annoying. But as time goes by it’s one of life’s little victories.Having said that, this hasn’t happened to me in Aldi. Maybe I ought to go to M&ampS!I’M truly appalled by the news that the Home Office “turns a blind eye” to the plight of British teenagers who are being forced to marry abroad, then raped and impregnated – after which the ministerial department actually hands a visa to their husbands.These young British women in question are forced abroad, or told they are going on holiday, but in reality are forced into a marriage and to get pregnant so that they can apply for a UK visa for their “husband”.Officials received dozens of reports last year that women wanted to block visas for men they had been made to marry in countries including Pakistan, India, Bangladesh and the United Arab Emirates.But in almost half of their cases the visas were approved nonetheless! And experts believe that there are thousands more victims who are too afraid to come forward.The women forced into this situation must be absolutely terrified, not least because their own family is complicit in this abuse.The authorities when granting the visa do not actually speak to the “wife”. There is no whistle-blowing process or opportunity for the women to make a confidential statement. Any statement made is public.Authorities fear that if they block the visa they will be called racists, but this is a safeguarding issue and that fear of causing offence really has to stop.We need to get on top of the problem by working with schools to raise awareness, so girls know how to report it.And we need to work with social workers so they can recognise the family members are the perpetrators of this crime.GOSH, how shocking is the video footage of a woman called Arabella Juniper Torres calling the police to report a woman, who happened to be black, for sheltering in her doorway in Brooklyn, New York, while waiting for her Uber?We are living in the age of the death of the Good Samaritan.I helped someone carry a pushchair downstairs at the Tube last week – as all the burly men walked past, I might add.She was so grateful it made me realise small acts of kindness have all but disappeared. How about this for an idea: let’s all try to be kind.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what happened to british male
story: I grew up in a typical working-class neighbourhood where all forms of violence against women were strictly taboo.Somewhere between my youth and today, that old taboo has vanished.I look at what we have become, a nation where violence against women is shockingly common, and I do not recognise it as the land I grew up in.In a sunny park, a pack of leering teenage boys pose proudly around a cowering middle-aged woman who they have ritually abused, pelting her with flour, water and eggs until she is bent into submission.At chucking-out time at an Essex nightclub, a young man punches a young woman in the face until she lies senseless on the pavement.What the hell has happened to the young British male?How did he ever become such a vicious, bullying, woman-hating coward?I saw violence and bullying when I was growing up in my little corner of Essex, but I never saw anything even remotely like these despicably ugly scenes.What kind of homes did these creeps grow up in?What do they imagine it takes to be a man? And how did they get so sick that they believe their behaviour is socially acceptable?These women-hating bullies — Liam Holmes, 20, who battered a woman to the ground outside Faces nightclub, and the five smirking thugs who tormented a vulnerable woman but can’t be named because they are under 18 — are not the products of brutal, inner-city gangland.These blights on the face of British manhood are the product of ordinary homes, God help us.They are what our young men look like now.They are not feral kids who never had a chance.They are not the products of deprived lives.The leering bullies posing proudly around their terrified victim in that sun-drenched park are growing up in Bury St Edmunds, a peaceful Suffolk market town with pretty cottages and a lovely cathedral, while Liam Holmes attacked his victim outside a club that was once a fashionable oasis for footballers and pop stars, the Essex answer to New York’s Studio 54.These thugs all have dear old mums who love them to bits.Indeed, the mother of one of the park scum sacks — a woman who must have an IQ lower than her dress size — complained that her son was the one suffering now because the backlash has ruined his 16th birthday.The poor little lamb! What’s the world coming to if you and your mates can’t torture a vulnerable middle-aged woman in the park any more?Personally, I hope the backlash ruins his life.And while we ponder these pitiful excuses for young men, let us spare a thought for their female victims.The 18-year-old woman who was punched to the ground by Liam Holmes has been predictably abused in the sewer of social media, informed “she deserved it” for daring to speak back to a man, and gloatingly told that, “she had a lesson in true equality.Meanwhile the vulnerable 49-year-old woman who was brutalised in the park has spoken with incredible restraint about her experience, which must have been as humiliating as it was frightening.“Considering the respective ages of all parties and that it was five or six young men versus me alone, I remain surprised that they behaved in such a way towards me,” she said.“I would like to hear their reasons, if possible.”Which is so mild-mannered that I find it breaks my bloody heart.It is tempting to blame the surge in violence against women on social media, and brainless morons like the little d**ks in that park taking pictures to show off to their mates. But it can’t all be blamed on social media.I bet Liam Holmes wishes there were no cameras around when he was smashing a woman in the jaw.“He wouldn’t do that for no reason,” protests his mother Cathy, 53. “There was a lot that went on before that people don’t know about.”Sorry, there can never be an excuse, reason or justification for a man or boy to abuse a woman or girl. Not ever.The old taboo about men being violent towards women should still stand.Lads, it doesn’t matter if they say something cutting to you at chucking out time.Lads, it doesn’t matter if they have the insolent cheek to sit on the park bench where you like to hang out with your bad-ass homies in the Bury St Edmunds massive.How hard is it to understand?Men should not be violent towards women.My father, the hardest man I ever met, taught me a real man does not raise his voice to a woman, let alone his hand.But that generation of tough, gentle men has gone and in their place we have pitiful excuses for the male of the species who feel empowered by belittling, beating and abusing women.And what sickens the stomach about the boys in the park is that they all look so very pleased with themselves, as if tormenting a vulnerable woman who, in the words of her stepmother “wouldn’t say boo to a goose” is the high point of their miserable lives.It is a good job their mothers all love them because I can’t imagine any other self-respecting woman ever will.“He’s never had a girlfriend,” someone remarked of woman-bashing lout, Liam Holmes.Yes, it shows. The big close-up Nicole posted on Instagram is absolutely terrifying. What a scary face! The spider, I mean. Not Nicole.HOW sweet life was for Jeremy Corbyn when he was a loopy left-wing backbencher, free to flutter his eyelashes at the IRA, to stand on platforms that compared Israel to Nazi Germany and to bowl up on Iranian TV praising the release of Hamas terrorists who had murdered Jewish children.But now fate has Corbyn as a possible Prime Minister his support of extremism is not such a good look.And no matter how pathetic this Tory Government becomes, no matter how timid, weak and gutless Theresa May looks in the face of Brussels’ bullying, the British people will never choose for Prime Minister a man who considers the child killers in Hamas to be his “brothers”.“In the past, in the pursuit of peace and justice for the Palestinian people, I have on occasion appeared on platforms with people whose views I completely reject,” apologises panicky Corbyn, a man who can feel the keys to 10 Downing Street slipping through his fingers.The past is coming back to haunt Jeremy Corbyn.And it will destroy him.It might also have something to do with the celeb fear of looking like a sweaty idiot with two left feet, while wearing nipple-crushing Lycra on prime-time television.Luckily, Nadiya Bychkova, above, will be there for her second series, the only pro dancer who looks more like a celebrity than any of the celebrities.THOSE who want the UK to remain in the European Union have never made any attempt to persuade the 17.4million who voted to leave to change our minds.They just insult us.Peter Mandelson says Brexiteers “hate other countries and hate foreigners” while Stewart Lee, a pot-bellied Bernard Manning for snowflakes, says: “It wasn’t just racists that voted to leave Europe – c**** did as well. Stupid f****** c****.”Just insults.Which is why Remain lost the referendum. And why they would lose 100 referendums.BAKE Off winner Nadiya Hussain tells Loose Women: “I work in an industry that is heavily dominated by male, middle-class, middle-aged men and there’s no space for a 5ft brown girl, who wears a headscarf.”But you became a national treasure, Nadiya.So self-pity is misplaced.MADONNA turns 60 years old on August 16 and has marked the birthday by laying provocatively on the ground sporting suspenders, lacy bra and a been-to-bed expression in her half-closed eyes.The Material Girl still looks great, of course.Mind you, she does look as though she might need a hand getting back on her feet. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corbyn not fit pm
story: That’s the only conclusion to draw from the cack-handed way he has dealt with the vicious anti-Semitism which seems to infect every corner of his Labour Party.His first response to the latest scandal was to stick his fingers in his ears and hum the Red Flag rather than address it head-on.Even when he was forced to break his silence, he could barely bother to do anything other than copy and paste from the last time he was compelled to apologise.It is shocking, but not particularly surprising.After all this is a man who has surrounded himself with anti-Semites for decades, and has been happy to trot out dangerous conspiracy theories himself.Why would he care that Jews within his own party feel unwelcome?Why would he care that Jewish leaders see him and his party as an ‘existential threat’ to their lives here?Labour MP Joan Ryan is calling for a proper investigation into Corbyn’s comments. Fine. But this leopard is not about to change his spots.Throughout his life he has shown terrible judgment. It is extraordinary how often he picks the wrong side.He is not just a threat to British Jews if he gets into power.He’s a threat to Britain, full stop.BRUSSELS bureaucrats always put their precious project ahead of common sense.It explains their approach to Brexit negotiations.Yet our analysis of what a ‘no deal’ Brexit would mean for French pharmaceutical companies, German car manufacturers and everything in between should focus minds.You can’t just find £500 billion down the back of the sofa, Jean-Claude.The Brexit Department has its own detailed study too, but are keeping it private. That should change.Let’s see if unleashing ‘Project Fear’ on the Continent helps our negotiating hand.THE death of Elsie Scully-Hicks is a heart-breaking tragedy.But our revelation today of a potential conflict of interest at the heart of the Vale of Glamorgan Council shows there are still serious questions to answer.There should be no stone unturned.We must ensure that nothing like this can ever happen again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: university top staff spending
story: As we reveal today, staff at 54 universities spent £204million in two years on company cards.University top brass have serious questions to answer.Students and taxpayers — who fund the majority of universities’ income — will rightly feel outraged at the grotesque details included in our probe.Universities serve today as get-rich-quick schemes for top staff.Third-rate colleges charge students the same as Oxford and Cambridge for Mickey Mouse degrees.Vice-chancellors pocket hundreds of thousands of pounds a year with salaries greater than the Prime Minister’s.Now it has been revealed staff get jollies on expenses, too.Meanwhile, the interest rates for students to pay back their £50,000 worth of debt is soon to rise to 6.3 per cent…Our university funding system is not working in the interests of students.It needs reforming ­— and quickly.BRITAIN is a nation of dog-lovers.Our four-legged friends heroically work alongside our police, fire services and armed forces.They assist the disabled. And they provide unconditional love for millions.Now, leading dog charities have warned that the consumption of dog meat here is on the rise.This sick trend cannot continue.Campaigners are calling on the Government to outlaw it.But it is horrifying that this is not already the case.America will enact legislation next month to make it illegal there.Our Government must do the same.THE Thomas Markle debacle cannot continue.How can Kensington Palace’s PR team think that forever snubbing him will help?It is about time something gave to stop this sad situation worsening.Prince Harry should step in to help orchestrate a positive resolution.The stress on Meghan, who is trying to adjust to life in Britain, is very unfair.IT is almost 40 years since Linda Lusardi first modelled for The Sun — becoming our most popular Page Three girl ever.Now, as she prepares to mark her 60th birthday, she has returned to her roots with a stunning new photo shoot.Like Madonna, who is about to reach the same milestone, she is proving age is nothing but a number.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn not fit pm
story: The ugly barb is a knee-jerk term of abuse favoured by the Left, usually accompanied by “fascist” — or “Nazi” if Ken Livingstone’s anywhere nearby.So it is richly amusing to see Jeremy Corbyn publicly embraced by the Ku Klux Klan as a fellow Jew-hater.It takes one to know one.Jezza has at least done us all a favour by coming out as a genuine lifelong racist and proving he is unfit to hold any proper job, let alone as Prime Minister of this country.Helpfully, he has also exposed Labour’s own enduring hypocrisy in selectively deciding who and what is “racist”. Only whites qualify.For decades, the likes of Harriet Harman have led the crusade for equality, attacking men as oppressors and demanding — rightly — that women must be protected from abuse.Harman famously refuses even to endorse marriage as the best foundation for raising a family, let alone as a good thing in itself, a public commitment.Yet she and the overwhelming majority of virtue- signalling Labour MPs are silent, for instance, on the treatment of some Muslim women by some Muslim men.I can’t recall a Labour street protest against forced ­marriage or honour killings even though they are commonplace here and reprehensible in any society. Even the Home Office feels cowed when dealing with victims.Indeed, Labour turned on its own brave MP Sarah Champion for daring to raise the issue of rampant sex-trafficking by “mainly Pakistani men”.On the Left, racism trumps rape. Now, like the “F-word”, it has become the reach-for term of abuse applied to any debate — including the issue of Britain leaving the European Union.Opposition to the EU’s ­corrupt and undemocratic “Grand Projet” long precedes the uncontrolled mass immigration unleashed by Labour.Illegal immigration is simply another symptom of EU “we know best” arrogance — personified by German Chancellor Angela Merkel.Yet preposterous Tory MP Anna “Suck-It-Up” Soubry routinely slurs 17.4million referendum voters as “racist”.It is the mantra of all those who see Brexit voters — more than half the country — as thick and nasty.Odious Peter Mandelson joined in last week, avoiding the “R-word” but ludicrously accusing anyone who wants to leave the EU of “hating foreigners”, which is the same thing.“Nationalism is a hatred of foreigners,” says the slippery Euro peer. “They should not be confused with patriots.”“I voted Remain in the referendum though I entirely respect the contrary view of many others.”Mandy’s relationship with the truth has always been flaky, but this is pure cant.Even those who once worked alongside Lord Mandelson when Labour still stood for something are appalled.Ex-Home Secretary and fellow Remainer David Blunkett snapped yesterday: “The allegation that some of those voting for Leave were ‘racist’ is not a new one.“It has been bandied about and seems to me not only an insult to the many people that I used to represent who voted Leave, but also to utterly miss the point of why the majority of British people voted the way they did.“If we fail to understand, then we do ourselves, but crucially also our democracy, a great disservice.”Lord Blunkett also slammed Mandy’s call for a second referendum.He is right. It is now clear the mood has hardened against bullying Brussels.The EU’s own snide insinuations that voters here are racist “Little Englanders” has not helped.Bank of England boss Mark Carney, architect of Project Fear, sank the Pound last week by claiming chances of a clean-break Brexit were “uncomfortably high”.Trade Secretary Liam Fox warns the odds are now 60-40 against a deal.Remainers should understand that every gratuitous insult to the intelligence of decent British voters is another nail in Theresa May’s chances of a friendly ­negotiated settlement.McDonnell, cleverer than Corbyn, wants to stop Labour being dragged into what deputy leader Tom Watson calls a “vortex of eternal shame”. But McDonnell, too, is stained by anti-Jewish sentiment.In any case, Britain needs Jeremy Corbyn – to remain in place as the sullen figurehead of a blinkered Marxist rabble and remind voters what they are risking at the next election.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teen girls double social media self harm
story: The number of hospital admissions for girls jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. Those being treated for an attempted overdose rose more than ten-fold — from 249 in 1997 to 2,736.As far as I am concerned, social media is almost entirely responsible.In a world where everyone relies on their phones for everything, there has never been a more worrying time for mental health.To be a teenage girl in this day and age is to be never alone — and always lonely.They are spending day after day wading through airbrushed photos of images society has deemed perfect.Whether it is a member of the Kardashian family posing with a diet pill, a boob job advert in the middle of Love Island or a photo of a friend with whitened teeth and smooth skin, our screens are filled with how we can be better — with how we SHOULD be better.Jon Goldin is vice chairman of the child and adolescent faculty at the Royal College of Psychiatrists.He  said recently: “There are a range of factors putting pressure on young children — academic pressure, exam pressure, social media . . . with fear of missing out and comparing yourself unfavourably to images you see online.“If you look at social media, my hunch is that girls are probably more sensitive to some of those factors than boys.”Although suicide is still the biggest killer of men under 45, awareness of this is at an all-time high. Hospital admissions for self-harm in boys, while still too high (2,236 last year), are stable.There was a campaign (which I took part in) two weeks ago that went viral on Instagram as people were asked to signal that they were OK as a means of opening a conversation on mental health.It is a conversation that desperately needs to be had.Despite massive steps to raise awareness, not least the Royal Family getting behind the Heads Together campaign for last year’s London Marathon, the internet — and young girls’ place in it — still needs a lot of talking about.I was lucky. Instagram was only invented when I was 16 and it did not matter a jot that I did not start using it until I was 18. Although we had social media, it was in its infancy, and I am incredibly grateful for that. My phone played a very small part in my life as a teenager.24% of girls are depressed by age 1480,000 UK kids suffer from severe depression90% of teen girls unhappy with their bodies70% of young people have been cyber-bulliedAs I went through the trials of being a young, insecure girl at school, negative thoughts were not able to follow me home. I would say goodbye to the bitching at 3.30pm and eat bangers and mash with my siblings without a thought for the girls in my class — no pinging from my phone to create waves of anxiety.These days that is simply not an option.Every issue that every teenager has ever faced is magnified to an extraordinary level with the advancement of technology.But removing phones from our daughters is simply not an option. Telling a teenager they can not have the internet is to tell them they can not have friends.Ten years ago a teenage friendship could withstand a summer holiday of no contact, but now a weekend with no signal, a Tuesday night with no Instagram story, makes kids hyperventilate.To be offline is to be forgotten. It is not showing up to the only party. The party that is going on all day and, more worryingly, all night too.Self-harm is, more often than not, a cry for help.As the internet forces its way into every corner of our lives, I cannot help but feel that it is a cry for human attention for affectionate, real-life attention.Warning signs  include if a child starts talking about themself in terms of failure or if there is a  change in their eating or sleeping patterns.Try asking  open-ended questions and do not give up if they are reluctant to  respond.Do not ban social media but set a good example and do activities away from it together.If you are affected by any of the issues raised in this article, please call the Samaritans (free) on 116 123.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels mad to knock brexit plan
story: We understand the frustration of those across the Continent who want to see a good deal struck — frustration at the PM’s failure to outline her position until nearly two years after the Referendum.And, whilst they aren’t the bureaucrats who sit round tables in Brussels — or have boozy lunches with Jean-Claude Juncker — there are plenty of business leaders and sensible politicians in European capitals who are desperate for Britain to sign a comprehensive trade pact.They understand that the future of the Continent’s economy is more important than the ideology of the true believers heading up the European Commission. The PM has — finally — started to talk to them with a concrete plan.The silence after her meeting with Emmanuel Macron is concerning, but the noises from German business leaders and politicians from the Continent in recent weeks are more promising.As the clock ticks, it’s time for them to tell Brussels that the theatrics and the anti-Britain briefings have to end. The Chequers fudge is not perfect. But Brussels would be mad to knock it back.And if they do? Planning is already stepping up for a clean-break Brexit.The PM still believes no deal is better than a bad deal and insists she’s ready to walk away.And that, as President Trump knows, is The Art Of The Deal…AND so another new front opens up in the war against the motorist.It’s outrageous that companies in some parts of the country could be charged if their employees drive to work.Those firms, who have already paid business rates for having a car park, will just pass on the extra cost to workers. Another stealth tax, another pocket emptied.We wouldn’t mind so much if we believed the money would be ploughed back into the roads, getting rid of potholes and fixing rocky road surfaces. Or if the trains turned up when they’re supposed to.But we won’t hold our breath.POLICE unions never fail to complain about overwork and stress on the job.We can understand why. It’s not an easy job. Coppers have our respect.But the news that one in 12 have second jobs suggests that not all of the wailing about long hours and working conditions are entirely legitimate.The next time a victim is told there’s nobody available to investigate, they might wonder what their local bobbies are up to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: border force staff holiday ban no deal brexit
story: Proposals have been sent to Home Secretary Sajid Javid as Whitehall panics about the consequences of the collapse of trade talks with the EU.Sources told The Sun that under one plan all 8,500 Border Force staff will be banned from taking leave in the four weeks from March 24 – five days before Britain is due to formally leave the EU.This would then be followed by a further four weeks of “significant restrictions” – meaning staff would only be allowed time off in exceptional circumstances over Easter. A separate plan details a two week outright ban followed by six weeks of restrictions.It’s the first significant sign of No Deal planning by the Home Office – despite repeated calls for the Government to do more to shore up Britain’s borders.Critics claim a No Deal will spark huge queues at ports due to explosion in physical checks on goods and people entering the UK.Lucy Moreton of the Immigration Services Union said staff were “paying the price” for their woeful lack of preparation by the Government and Border Force over the past two years.The Home Office is recruiting some 300 extra Border Force staff for Brexit – but union leaders claims TEN TIMES as many are required.Ms Moreton stormed: “Beleaguered staff who already have had to give up summer family holidays may now be asked to give up Easter holidays as well just to paper over the gaps caused by years of under investment.“We have repeatedly warned Border Force of the need for far greater preparation in case of the catastrophic impact of a No Deal.“Now our members are paying the price.”A No Deal effectively means all existing agreements and alliances with the EU end overnight on March 29.Leaked documents last week suggested the Home Office may allow EU citizens to enter the UK without checks in the event of a No Deal because Border Force doesn’t have the capacity to cope.It currently takes 45 seconds to check an EU citizens’ passport compared to an average four minutes for someone from the rest of the world.But non-EU tourists have faced huge delays of up to 3.5 hours at Heathrow this summer as staffing shortages cause huge tailbacks at border control.A Home Office spokesman last night said: “We have made significant progress in negotiations and are confident of securing a deal with the EU.“However it is the duty of any responsible government to prepare for every eventuality, including the unlikely scenario that we reach March 2019 without agreeing a deal.” Our journalists strive for accuracy title: dame margaret hodge jeremy corbyn labour leadership purging critics
story: The veteran Labour MP - spared the threat of any disciplinary action over the bitter anti-Semitism row on Monday - tore into the Labour leadership for trying to “purge” its critics.And she insisted that ‘moderates’ would soon get their party back from the clutches of the hard-left.She stormed: “Labour has been going for 100 years, Jeremy has been leader for three. This period is a blip in our history.“We will overcome this.”The incendiary comments - that threaten another huge backlash from ‘Corbynistas’ - came as a second Labour MP suspended in the anti-Semitism row threatened legal action.Lawyers acting for Ian Austin – a former Labour minister – said the investigation into the MP was a “farce and a disgrace” and an attempt to silence “legitimate criticism”.The row was sparked last month when Labour’s ruling body approved a new anti-Semitism code condemned by the Jewish community for watering down the internationally recognised IHRA definition.Mr Austin condemned the move in a tirade at party chair Ian Lavery – triggering disciplinary action. At the same time Margaret Hodge branded Jeremy Corbyn an “anti-Semite”.Labour ended an investigation into Dame Margaret on Monday claiming she had “expressed regret” - a claim she immediately denied.Mr Corbyn faced fresh humiliation as footage from an interview with Iranian TV in 2011 showed the Labour leader appearing to question Israel’s right to exist.He accused the Israeli Government and Israeli Embassy of pressurising the BBC into defending it.And UK experts who helped draw up the IHRA code condemned Labour by saying any “modified” version of its ‘gold standard’ code would allow attacks on Jews to go “unaddressed”.In a withering attack, the UK delegation of the global watchdog said any “modified” version of its gold standard would leave attacks on the Jewish community “unaddressed”.While not naming Labour, the seven UK academics said they were issuing the statement in light of the recent “discourse” on anti-Semitism.Labour’s ruling NEC body triggered the bitter row last month by approving plans for its own anti-Semitism code – which critics claim has dropped four of the 11 examples listed by the IHRA.In their statement, the UK experts said: “Any ‘modified’ version of the IHRA definition that does not include all of its 11 examples is no longer the IHRA definition.Adding or removing language undermines the months of international diplomacy and academic rigour that enabled this definition to exist.We would once again revert to a world where antisemitism goes unaddressed simply because different entities cannot agree on what it is.”Labour MP Wes Streeting – co-chair of the All-Party Parliamentary Group for British Jews – said it was time for the Labour leadership to “swallow its pride” and accept the IHRA definition in full. He said: “I think this demonstrates conclusively that any individuals or organisations including the Labour Party cannot cherry pick the bits that they like from the IHRA definition and disregard others. “I think after a summer of utter misery for the Labour party over its failure to tackle anti-Semitism it’s time for the leadership to swallow its pride and acknowledge they have got this badly wrong.” Our title: theresa may held talks with snp leader nicola sturgeon
story: It came as respected pollster Sir John Curtice said the odds were stacked against her holding a Scottish independence referendum within five years.Ms Sturgeon hinted last night she will delay her announcement on a second vote – whoch was expected in October.The SNP leader said the half-hour bilateral talks with the Prime Minister failed to allay her fears the UK is heading towards a No Deal Brexit.Questioned on what this means for her pledge to update MSPs on her Scottish independence plans in late 2018, she said: “Presumably when we get to October I will give an update.Pushed on whether she would ever accept a request for IndyRef2 , Mrs May said: “The Scottish people voted in 2014, they had a referendum, they gave a clear decision that they wanted Scotland to remain part of the United Kingdom and I believe what we should be doing now is working to get on with the job of delivering on the future of the United Kingdom.“That’s about Brexit, it’s about getting a good Brexit deal, it’s about all the other issues like the industrial strategy and like the city deal that i’ve just talked about.“What I want to see is the Scottish Government also putting forward their support for the proposals that we’ve put forward to the European Union that would deliver on the vote but would also deliver for Scotland and deliver for the rest of the UK.”Nicola Stugeon hinted she will delay her announcement on a second Scottish voteThe PM said: Were negotiating as the United Kingdom.I think its incumbent on all parts of the United Kingdom to be supportive of the proposals we are putting forward in their interaction with Brussels, and I think its important that we see those proposals being supported, rather than, sadly, what I fear well see here, which is an attempt to sow the politics of division. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: adrian chiles it is better to be a pessimist
story: I read this in The Sun yesterday morning and choked on my toast. I wasn’t surprised I choked on my toast because anything bad that happens to me — big or small — I’ve already lived through in my imagination.But I choked at the sheer obviousness of the scientists’ conclusions. Of course feeling stressed helps people deal with bad news. What next? Scientists discover sleep is related to tiredness?I can deal with bad news better because I’ve already been in that moment. I’m well prepared because I’ve actually lived it in my head.Anyway, the choking passed and, to my surprise, I didn’t die. That’s another beauty of always believing the worst will happen. What a wonderful surprise it is when the worst doesn’t happen.The toast didn’t kill me. I cheated the choke. Oh, the joy.I don’t know how long I’ve been this way. It’s definitely been going on since I was a kid.I remember flying off on holiday to what was then Yugoslavia with my mum and dad. I recall my mum trying to talk to me about all the exciting things we’d be doing when we got to my nan’s house on the Adriatic.I kept shaking my head and not saying anything and she got annoyed and rolled her eyes, thinking I just wasn’t looking forward to our holiday.But she misunderstood me. I didn’t want to think about the nice things we’d be doing because I was so convinced the plane was going to crash that it made me sad to consider what I surely wouldn’t experience.Imagine, then, my joy when the plane didn’t actually crash and I ended up not dying. What a bonus!And I went in the sea and didn’t drown — another nice surprise.I almost look forward to the moment when I do croak. If I have any warning I’ll tut and say to myself, “Oh well, I knew this would happen sooner or later.”This kind of attitude is admittedly a disaster when it comes to wooing women. Assuming total failure ahead of any move made on the opposite sex is disastrous. It’s just not attractive.I’ve a friend who simply cannot imagine why any woman in the world wouldn’t desire him.Consequently, many women do desire him. I, on the other hand, simply cannot imagine why any woman would desire me. Consequently, they invariably don’t. But because I knew they wouldn’t, I’m not remotely downhearted.I’ve kept the company of positive people over the years. They have their uses. But expecting me to believe them when they say, “Don’t worry, it’ll all be fine”, is fanciful.And believing that from professional advisers can be absolutely calamitous.“Oh yes, Adrian, it’s all going to be fine.” And then, whatever it is, turns out not to be fine and they just shrug and say, “Oh dear, didn’t see that coming, pay me some more fees and I’ll make sure it’ll be all right in the end.”In my work as a journalist I’ve talked to many psychologists who speak of the power of positive thinking. Yeah, whatever. Maybe. But what I do know for sure is that I just can’t do it.When you’re standing on a golf course with a club in your hand addressing the ball, you’re supposed to envisage your perfect shot. For me, impossible.What I actually envisage, with complete clarity, is a truly dreadful shot.I can actually hear the ball smacking on to trees, or plopping into water. I’m living in the calamity.So at least when it happens, which is often, I can shrug and say, “Hmm, thought so.”All this may stem from supporting a team like West Bromwich Albion. I once told a priest, in all seriousness, that I suffered from deep despondence.When he asked me why I thought this was, I told him (as a joke) who I supported. He nodded gravely and said, “Yes, I see, I see.”I have a friend I travel with on the supporters’ coaches to away matches. The poor chap always thinks we’re going to win. Even at 2-0 down at half-time he’ll be sure we’ll emerge victorious.I challenged him once about these absurd delusions and he said: “Look, we all have the same journey home after a game. If we’ve won we’re both happy, if we lose we’re both sad. The difference is that I’ve had a much more enjoyable journey there than you.”That convinced me for a while. So the next game I tried being positive.And we lost. And it hurt more. So I went back to how I was.There’s only one route to happiness I can think of and it’s to be found in the lyrics of a song by the late Mose Allison: “I don’t worry ’bout a thing, ’cos I know nothing’s going to be alright.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
