title: self harming kids online trolls jane moore
story: She smoked (fags and pot), she drank alcohol (often in front of her liberal parents), always had what my mother would consider to be unsuitable boyfriends and was effortlessly academic, particularly at maths.Often, as we walked home from school chatting away, she would casually drag the back of her hand along a brick wall, causing the flesh to swell angrily and bleed.Other times she’d quietly press a lit cigarette into her palm, her expression never changing.“Why do you do that?” I’d ask.“It makes me feel better,” she’d say with a shrug.Sarah (not her real name) was, as I now know it, a self-harmer. But in those days — the late Seventies — it was rare and unrecognised.We lost touch a long time ago, but I thought of Sarah this week when I read that the number of teenage girls self-harming has doubled in the past 20 years.According to new NHS data, the number of hospital admissions for girls who have self-harmed has jumped from 7,327 in 1997 to 13,463 last year. For boys, the figures have stayed almost the same — from 2,236 then to 2,332 now.Worse, “self-poisoning” — as in taking an overdose — is rising for both genders and last month the Government released a green paper that said around 850,000 children and young people now have a diagnosable mental health condition.Experts say academic pressure is a contributory factor, so too social media.Kids have always had exams to cope with but in the old days jealous and bitter remarks were confined to the dark corners of secret conversations or, at worst, scrawled on a toilet wall.Now these brave warriors have a keyboard and pseudonym behind which they can troll you for everyone to see.By my age, you know the vitriol probably comes from a bitter, 53-year-old virgin who lives in his mother’s spare bedroom. But when you’re still finding your way in the world, that poisonous undermining can worm its way inside your head and chip away at the confidence that acts as an armour in life.One self-harmer told me the pain of cutting his skin provided a welcome distraction from the “washing machine” rotations of negative thoughts constantly disturbing his peace of mind.The majority of them can be helped if it is spotted early enough and the expert assistance they need is then easy to access. And therein lies the problem.In 2016, Theresa May said the mental health of children was to be one of her priorities as PM, but since then Brexit has taken over and little has changed.The Government’s strategy is to train more teachers to spot the signs, appoint 7,000 more specialists to child mental health units and cut the waiting time for non-critical cases to be seen.But even if it happens, it won’t be enough.Parents must also remain vigilant for any marked change in their child’s personality or behaviour and the big social media companies have the technology to stop the majority of trolls — so they should be forced to use it.If all of the above doesn’t happen, the NHS has another mental health time bomb coming which will cost the taxpayer a fortune and have an even greater cost to the mental well-being of the next generation.WHEN TV baker Paul Hollywood started dating a 23-year-old barmaid from his local pub, they were quick to point out that their relationship only started after his marriage to wife Alex ended.But Alex is reportedly not buying this explanation and is planning to name Summer Monteys-Fullam in her £10million divorce battle.Whatever the truth, it remains the case that many couples conveniently consider only full sexual intercourse as adultery.But of course, cosy chats, lingering touches and come-hither looks are all it takes for any man with a wandering eye to recognise that, should he wish to jump ship, there’s a shiny new model waiting in the wings to rev up his sex life.Hallelujah for the wonderfully pragmatic Emma Thompson who, when asked about her marriage to the dreamily handsome Greg Wise, replied that they have had plenty of rough times.The secret to a happy relationship, she says, is the realisation that there will be unhappy times and that, if you manage to amble through to the other side: “It’s always better.”She adds: “I think people in long, happy marriages tell a lot of fibs, like, ‘Yes, it’s been marvellous’, whereas I say, ‘Sometimes it has been awful’.”If a relationship is deeply unhappy for a sustained period then, of course, get the hell out.But in these Tinder times of endlessly sweeping left in search of the “perfect” mate (who doesn’t exist) it’s invaluable when someone high profile points out that, more often than not, sticking with the one you’ve got works out in the end.Altogether now, “Love is a decision, not just a feeling.”Daisy-May Demetres smile lights up a room.Just eight years old, she was born without her lower legs and now uses two prosthetic blades that allow her to live as full a life as possible.She attends mainstream school, loves PE and has just been given a modelling contract with high street brand River Island.Yet, because of her disability, her parents Alex and Claire admit to feeling a “profound sadness” the day she was born and asked themselves what they had done wrong. And when, as a toddler, Daisy-May had to endure a painful, eight-hour operation on her stumps, Alex admits he turned to alcohol and gambling in a bid to numb his feelings of hopelessness.But by the time she was four, Daisy-May had mastered her blades and was doing cartwheels and headstands.Alex, 35, from Birmingham, says: “I looked at her and thought, ‘If you can achieve so much, against all the odds, and still be cheerful, then I have no reason at all to be depressed’. I stopped gambling and drinking that day.”While no one would wish disability on their child, the Demetres’ story is a salutary lesson that, sometimes, what seems like insurmountable adversity through an adult’s eyes can, through a child’s simple acceptance and joie de vivre, enrich your life and give it deeper meaning.Following a cyber attack in Alaska, government officials have abandoned their computers and taken to using old-fashioned typewriters.Let joy be unconfined.I still have my original typewriter from my days as a junior reporter on the Solihull News and it was a loyal servant that never crashed, froze or ran out of battery. I may even request for it to be buried with me.It seems that my love for these machines is rivalled only by Tom Hanks (yes, that one) who has written a book of short stories about them and created an app called the Hanx Writer, which emulates the glorious click-clack sound as you type.Go on, try it. There’s no greater pleasure.No? Just me then...Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit breach rules
story: Expert Professor David Collins said there was a major risk of the UK breaching World Trade Organisation rules on tariffs and trade.After examining the PM’s White Paper he said there was a “serious” chance “at least two” parts of the Facilitated Customs Arrangement (FCA) that would break international trading laws.Prof Collins said the worst case scenario was that the FCA would have to be abandoned, or significantly modified.He said: “It is difficult to see what modifications could successfully address these potential illegalities without destroying the whole purpose of the FCA”.The academic said the PM’s blueprint would also “severely constrain” the UK’s ability to sign free trade agreements with other countries.He added: “It is hard to believe that a third country would agree to offering lower tariffs to UK exports when that third country’s exports to the UK would be subject to a higher EU tariff at the border, subject to the promise that there will be a rebate at a later stage pursuant to a cumbersome tracking procedure.”And he warned foreign traders would find the system overcomplicated meaning they could decide against exporting to the UK and EU because of the confusing tariff system.He said: “It would give us free trade. Europe’s three biggest economies outside Britain are huge exporters to the UK — Germany, France, Italy.“They’d demand free trade from the EU. I guarantee my entire wealth we’d get it.” He said our Brexit team lacked “the art of the deal”. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: british airways staff sacked man bun
story: Londoner Sid Ouared, 26, said he has been discriminated against because he was accepted into the customer service role with the hairstyle.And the young man defended his hairstyle on Good Morning Britain this morning, arguing he had only been informed about the companys policy on tattoos and piercings (not hairstyles) before getting the customer service job.Speaking on Good Morning Britain, Sid said: Would you hire someone, say had they stated they had their hair at length for religious reasons.Say for example, Im a Christian so thats the reason why I have my hair at length.Host Kate Garraway then pointed out there were many Christians who didnt have man buns.But Sid added: Yeah, thats fair to say, however on the BA guidelines it only recognises the Sikh faith and the Rastafarian faith.Which is why they actually gave me three options - cut it, apply a turban or apply dreadlocksHow could I possibly because Im not a Sikh, nor am I a Rastafarian.But viewers were less than impressed with Sids argument - with many saying he should cut his hair if he really wanted the job.Writing on Twitter, one viewer pointed out: If you love the job that much youll do what you can to keep it, in this case get a hair cut.Rules are there for a reason and unfortunately he didnt adhere to them.Another added: His hair is ridiculous and yes it looks like a woman’s hair do if u want a good job cut it off simple you look stupid.A third simply added: Cut your hair hippie!Another said: If you want the job soooooo much comply with rules... Id like to fly in my boxers but I know its not allowed so going on GMB will not alter... Just making a name for himself.But more so why is religion always thrown in the pot.But others agreed with Sid when he argued that he should have been told about the dress code before being given the job.One wrote: To be fair BA should have addressed his hair/man bun before his first day of employment! Not 2 weeks in it just undermines their policy.Sid claimed it was only in his first week of work that a superior employee told him his hair needed to change, describing it as girls hair.When asked whether he had considered cutting his hair to keep his job, Sid argued: I dont feel like thats the point.The young man said he was now exploring other avenues for the future - saying he was going to look into a career with BA still.He said: Right now we live in multicultural Britain. We live in the age of equality and we should be open-minded.I have worked with lots of luxury retailers and never had an issue with my hair.A British Airways spokesman said: We dont comment in detail on individual employment matters.

title: rochdale paedo ring members deported
story: Abdul Aziz, Adil Khan and Qari Abdul Rauf were among nine men jailed over appalling crimes against teenage girls in the Greater Manchester town in 2012.Girls in their early teens were raped and pimped out to paying customers in Rochdale and Oldham.The horrific crimes were portrayed in three-part BBC drama Three Girls earlier this year.Then Home Secretary Theresa May ordered in 2015 that the beasts, born in Pakistan, have their citizenship revoked.The decision was a prelude to Government plans to deport them.But the men — convicted of trafficking girls for sexual exploitation — argued the ruling breached their human right to a family life.The trio, all of whom have British children, challenged the decision in the courts.But their campaign to stay British failed today when senior judges ruled that stripping them of citizenship is conducive to the public good.Lord Justice Sales told the Court of Appeal hearing that their exploitation of vulnerable girls in Rochdale amounted to serious organised crime.The judge, who had first jailed them at Liverpool Crown Court in May 2012, said victims were raped callously, viciously and violently.In some cases, they were driven round Rochdale and Oldham to be made to have sex with paying customers.All the men treated the girls as though they were worthless and beyond all respect.He added: They were motivated by lust and greed.Aziz, who was one of the ringleaders of the grooming gang and referred to by some of the others as The Master, was jailed for nine years.Married father-of-five Abdul Rauf was jailed for six years and Khan for eight years.But Lord Justice Sales warned that a deportation order would allow the men another right to appeal on human rights grounds — a process that is likely to take many months.The vile Rochdale group exploited girls as young as 13 and were initially handed sentences ranging from four to 19 years.The men — eight of Pakistani origin and one from Afghanistan — gave their victims drink and drugs  before “passing them” round for sex.The abuse took place at two takeaway restaurants — now under new management — in the Heywood area.One 15-year-old victim told their initial trial that she was ordered to sleep with a takeaway worker as a treat.

title: monks ghost spotted tintern abbey
story: Urban explorer Rosie Boulton, 19, made the spooky sighting at the historic site where Black Death wiped out monks in 1348.Travelling to several haunted locations a week, Rosie is constantly on the road snapping pictures of ruins.While visiting Tintern Abbey at night, Rosie and her friends didn’t find anything unusual, but remember feeling creeped out at the Monmouthshire site.However, when she returned home and looked at her images she spotted the ghostly vision her camera had captured.What looks like a hooded figure can be seen in the photographs standing in front of the ruins.Having always believed in ghosts and the paranormal, she couldn’t believe her luck and can’t wait to visit the location again.Rosie, from Stanford Bridge, Worcs, said: “I get an adrenaline rush, especially when it’s dark because it sets that eerie vibe.“I felt okay at the beginning but it was a huge place which made it feel a little more spooky.“You’re not supposed to go there at night. We felt like someone was coming towards us so we all ran out as we were scared.“I didn’t know about the ghost of the monk until I got home and looked back at the pictures.“I was on my own going through the photos and it just freaked me out. I called my friend and told her about the photos straight away.Tintern Abbey stands by the River Wye and was founded by the Cistercian monks in 1131 AD and was the only the second Cistercian foundation in Britain – the first in Wales.The current ruins are a mixture of building works from 1131 to 1536, with little remaining of the first structures. It still boasts vast windows and soaring archways.There have been many ghostly sightings of monks and other spiritual entities in the abbey.The Black Death in 1348 saw many of the monks perish, and some claim to see their spirits within the halls of the abbey, lined up and holding torches.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brazen motorists drive through farmers field to avoid 11 mile diversion after roadworks block 800 yard street
story: Dozens of vehicles have been filmed driving across the recently mowed hay field in Lakenheath, Suffolk after a 20-metre section of main road was closed to traffic.The off-road route has become popular amongst impatient motorists who dont want to face the longer journey to get to the other side of the village.The field leads on to the back of residential homes where neighbours say cars have been cutting through the area.The roadworks are blocking a section of the B1112 which residents use to travel less than half a mile from one end of the village to the other.Drivers face a staggering 11 mile diversion to get from Mutford Green to Hall Drive in the village - if the road is closed - via Station Road, Wingfield Road, Brandon Road, and Little Hemsworth.When the footage of motorists using the shortcut was shared on social media, exasperated homeowners blasted the drivers as disgraceful.Susan North, who often walks her dog around the same field, says it is a bit intimidating and there are not many places I can get off the track to let vehicles pass.Mark Hayes added: Blimey there are some really lazy drivers out there.Ruth Tierny wrote: Name &amp shame them!! Disgraceful.Although there was an uproar among the residents, a lot of people stuck up for the drivers because the roadworks can be an inconvenience.Lisa Waller wrote on Facebook: No defence for the drivers, but maybe show a little urgency in the works so people dont feel the need to off-road it across the fields.Liam Donovan added: If its a main used road with no close by diversion sign dont close the whole road down, work on one side then when you have finished work on the other you can keep the traffic going - its been done many times.What do you expect. Today I drove past an open barrier saying road closed, to find the work being done on one side.Other people was diverting for no reason you have got to chance it sometimes because 80 per cent of times it says road closed it nothing turns out to be happening.No offence to the workers though, this is just what I come across on a daily driving job.And one person particularly stuck up for the drivers, as Renier Jansen wrote: Love it! If there is a will there is a way!

title: moment aldi customer opens crisp pack to find just one cheese curl
story: Mark Murray was amused to supposedly find the underweight pack  - which should contain 12g of crisps -  in a multipack, and uploaded a video to Aldis Facebook page.The 26-year-old, from Beccles, bought the light snack from a store in Lowestoft, Suffolk.The clip starts with Mark, a forklift driver, holding the yellow packet and commenting: “Got a packet of crisps from Aldi, a multipack, you can see there’s air in it, it’s not been opened.”It appears that Mark then opens the packet and drops a single curl on to the table - he then turns the opened packet to the camera to show no other curls are lurking inside.He comments: “One Crisp. Thanks Aldi.”He sarcastically captioned the footage: “Full up from my lunch now.”On social media, Jason Downing said: “This is the best thing ever.”Robert Daley commented: “And that’s why you don’t shop at Aldi! S***e!”Julia Murray said: “Hahahah I can’t stop laughing ‘cor, one crisp, thanks Aldi.’”Carne Brighton said: “This would literally ruin my day.”Speaking about the snack, Mark said: “It was disbelief to be honest, at the same time it was hilarious.“I had put the video on the Aldi UK Facebook page and they got back to me with an automated message about coming back with a receipt and replace them.“I couldn’t be bothered with doing that over a packet of crisps though. I just see the funny side of it.”An Aldi spokesperson said:  We have apologised to Mr Murray for any inconvenience caused and have raised this with our supplier.”

title: baby passes out pakistan international airlines flight heat
story: The woman was heard pleading for help when her child got into breathing difficulties on board the Pakistan International Airlines flight from Paris to Islamabad.According to Geo News, the aircraft, which had been delayed on the tarmac for two hours last Friday, had faulty air conditioning.Passengers were reportedly forced to remain on board the sweltering plane for more than two hours before finally taking off, while staff reportedly guarded the door and refused to open it to allow ventilation.The hysterical mother was seen fanning the baby to try and cool it down as she yelled at flight attendants for several minutes.Several other people then surrounded staff to demand the door was opened, chanting shame, reports Pakistani news outlet Dawn.The airline insisted the flight was only delayed for 30 minutes while the pilot waited for clearance to depart from Air Traffic Control.Following the incident, the companys president Dr Musharraf Rasool Cyan today ordered a detailed inquiry into what happened.Filmed by another passenger, the video was posted on social media today and has gone viral with more than 100,000 views.It shows the woman berating two male staff members while a man stands beside her holding the baby.The child appears to be frothing slightly at the mouth and struggling to keep its eyes open.A crowd of angry passengers surrounds the flight attendants as they apologise profusely and try their best to calm them down.One of the men calls for instructions on the phone but the crowd becomes more irate when he apparently tells them he cannot open the door.The mother picks up the baby and fans the child with a sheet of paper while continuing to shout for help.Another small child being held by a parent is seen looking up at the camera and appears to be in some discomfort due to the stifling heat.The mother eventually gives up and returns to her seat with the baby as other customers continue to argue in vain with the staff.It is unclear whether the flight took off or not.But the social media account which posted the video clip said the baby was unharmed.In a statement released on Facebook, the nations flagship airline said: PIA has taken serious notice of the unfortunate incident that took place on PK750.“The president and CEO Dr Musharraf Rasool Cyan has taken immediate and serious notice and has asked for a detailed inquiry into the matter.The delay was for 30 minutes as doors were closed, aircraft was ready for push back.“However, Air Traffic Controller clearance was not received and the aircraft could not start its engine as the aircraft was still parked at the jetty.“Details of the incident and explanations are being given to the Captain in Command, the ground handler and PIAs chief operating officer.Zero tolerance policy has been adopted in PIA and there shall be no compromise on customer convenience and comfort.

title: uk heatwave end temperatures drop
story: But all is not lost as forecasts suggest we are in for the hottest Autumn in 38 years — with above average temperatures more than ten times as likely as colder ones.The Met Office said bitter air from Greenland – shown on dramatic new weather maps — will cause highs nosedive to 16-21C for most from tomorrow and into the weekend.Showers will also affect many northern areas from Thursday, with rain sweeping over the rest of the country from tomorrow and into the weekend.Former BBC and Met Office forecaster John Hammond of Weathertrending said temperatures are falling off a cliff with no return to June and July’s long hot and dry spells.But September has promise as the hottest late summer and early autumn for 38 years is on the cards.Next week will bring highs mainly around average for most — before the end of the month sees a potential warmer spell, the Met Office said.Netweather forecaster Paul Michaelwhite said: “This cooler spell is likely to last a week or more.After mid-month, there are hints high pressure may well build to allow another warm spell – but it’s a long way off and there are no guarantees.”Mr Hammond added: “August will turn into a very different month to June and July. Temperatures will fall off a cliff.“A huge atmospheric block prevented the jet stream from delivering wet weather from the Atlantic – but that block has finally been dislodged, and further weather systems will arrive.”A Met Office forecaster said: “It is turning cooler as the jet stream is diving south, steering progressively cooler air from Greenland and Iceland towards western Europe.“From Sunday to August 21, temperatures will generally be around normal.Spells of rain or showers are likely to push southeastwards.“From August 22 to September 5, the North of the UK is likely to see the driest weather.Temperatures are likely to be above normal, and many areas may become warm or very warm.”The Met Office said much hotter-than-normal UK conditions over the three months until the end of October are a huge 11 times more likely than much cooler conditions.The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “The Met Office forecast is astonishing.“September has 27C possible in Scotland, and even warm temperatures into October.”The Met Office three-month forecast said: “For August-October, the probability the UK average temperature will fall into the warmest of our five categories is around 55 per cent.The coldest of our five categories is less than 5 per cent.”This year is twice as likely as usual to have the hottest August to October period since before 1981, the Met Office forecast shows, due to more warm high pressure forecast.

title: storm tornado sunset amazing entries weather photographer competition
story: Arranged by the Royal Meteorological Society (RMetS) and AccuWeather, the deadline for entries was on June 5.“Weather impacts everything we do,” said Brian Lavery, Managing Director, Europe for AccuWeather.“We have seen countless examples of how and when the Superior Accuracy of our forecasts kept people safe and out of harm’s way.“I’m looking forward to seeing these captured moments that illustrate how we live alongside nature.”In what is the third edition of the photography competition, entries have come flooding in from across the world, with amateurs and professionals capturing the very best of Mother Nature.Images sent in for consideration included weather phenomena like stunning cloud formations, crisp lightening strikes and awe-inspiring sunsets.A mirror image of sunrise at Worthing Pier by Steven PastonThe overall winner of the competition will receive a £500 cash prize, an Olympus TG-5 Tough camera and one years membership to the Royal Meteorological Society.

title: why one man is driving 30000km to spell out brexit message
story: Beginning on 16 July, Mr Pardy set off from Loch Lomond in Scotland bound for the Port of Stranraer, his springboard to Northern Ireland.He carried on driving into the Republic of Ireland to complete the first curve of his "s", before turning to Wales and back again to Cornwall to complete the first letter.Since then he has completed letters "t" and "o", which took him a "mammouth" journey just to get to the start point - Gothenburg in Sweden.When he spoke to Sky News, Mr Pardy was setting off on his journey to draw a "p", this time venturing to the Arctic Circle, to begin in Norway's third most populated town, Narvik. "I'm making the most of our last summer inside the EU by embracing the concept of free movement and embarking on a farewell tour," he said.Asked why he was undertaking the mission, Mr Pardy said: "Freedom of movement is something I'm passionate about."I believe the ability to explore as well as live and work abroad without tiresome red tape is an immense privilege and, although we don't yet know to what extent this might be affected, I wanted to highlight some of the benefits as they stand&#8230"I've met lots of lovely people along the way who have been really supportive and have even offered up recommendations.

title: meghan markles make up artist
story: NewsMeghan Markle's make-up artist reveals one thing Prince Harry kept saying after wedding - and it's very sweetPrince Harry had an incredibly sweet message for Meghan Markle's make-up artist after their royal weddingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer09:24, 8 AUG 2018Updated11:39, 8 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe world collectively swooned as they watched Prince Harry tell his bride she looked 'amazing' as she met him at the altar on May 19.  And indeed Meghan Markle did look amazing in her Givenchy wedding dress, Queen Mary's diamond bandeau tiara and a fresh face of make-up by a celebrity make-up artist.  People across the world shared snaps of the Duchess of Sussex on her big day, commenting on her beauty and the natural look she chose for the ceremony - with her freckles on display for all to see.  And it's all thanks to Daniel Martin .   The make-up pro is a favourite among the likes of Elisabeth Moss and Olivia Palermo and he scored big brownie points with Meghan's new husband after working his magic on her face. Now he's revealed the one thing the prince kept saying to him after the ceremony - and it's very sweet.  Speaking to InStyle magazine , he said: After the ceremony Harry kept saying thank you. He was thanking me for making her look like herself.   The Duke of Sussex was so impressed with Meghan's look, he personally took the time to thank her make-up artist.   Daniel said he chose the natural look because he wanted the bride to be anything but trendy. The last thing you want is to look at your wedding pictures and go, 'remember when highlighting was the rage' he explained. At the end of the day, you want to look like your best self. But it was easy for him to make over Meghan, as he says he knows exactly what she does and doesn't like.

title: gareth thomas dont sell wembley
story: NewsopinionGareth Thomas: Don't sell Wembley Stadium - tax the TV rights billions to fund grassroots football insteadInstead of flogging Wembley to fund grassroots sport, we need a 10% levy on TV rights, writes north London MP Gareth ThomasShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByGareth Thomas MP15:11, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionThere must be a better way to fund grassroots sport, writes Gareth Thomas MP (Image: Alex Morton)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email We shouldn't be selling off Wembley Stadium - the iconic home to England’s football team and a huge money-spinner.  The Football Association says it would plough a windfall into grassroots sport for 20 years. But there are other, better ways to do this. As the Premier League kicks off this weekend, it continues to receive at least &pound3billion from domestic and overseas TV rights. It’s not hard to see how England’s richest clubs have so much money to share around between themselves. So the FA should be demanding the government introduce a levy of 10% on the TV income Premier League clubs receive.  This would help nurture the next generation of Harry Kanes, Jordan Pickfords, and Kieron Trippiers. Grassroots football in England is, unfortunately, not as healthy as the Premier League's prize pot. Only one in three grass pitches are of adequate quality to play football in England, and last season one in six matches were cancelled due to poor facilities. Meanwhile taxpayers paid out more than &pound160million to build Wembley. So any decision to sell off this nationally important venue should not be taken before other alternatives have been exhausted. The Premier League currently puts just &pound100million into grassroots football- a pitiful contribution given how wealthy its clubs are.

title: its ridiculous anyone would go
story: NewsopinionIt's ridiculous anyone would go around talking like Boris Johnson - which is exactly why he does itBoris Johnson is the MP for Boris Johnson, and that's the only principle he's gotShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist12:23, 8 AUG 2018Updated12:31, 8 AUG 2018NewsopinionGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe scene is a townhouse in north London. The honourable Member of Parliament for Boris Johnson is considering his next move. The Opposition is making headlines by chewing its own entrails over whether or not it likes Jews. The country is stockpiling food and medicines, while grass fires rage, cows go hungry and farmers talk of disaster. To make matters worse, he is being made to look incompetent by Jeremy Hunt, of all people, and Jacob Rees-Mogg is being spoken of as the next Prime Minister because he sounds clever. Grumble grumble and bugger me, Marina, but old Boris is benched! No-one is talking about Brilliant BJ. Damned impolite when I resigned on a matter of principle, having not displayed one iota of principle for the entirety of the 54 years I have given humanity the benefit of my existence. Well, I had a call on the telephoney-what-not the other day from Steve Bannon, you know, the man who looks like a suppurating tumour and got Donald Trump elected. He said I can take control of the news by saying mad and bonkers stuff, more mad and bonkers than normal anyway, not British bonkers but Trumpian bonkers. The fake news will faithfully report it all and the racists will love me, and all the racists-but-pretending-they-aren't will say they're supporting my economic policies.  So I asked the editor of the Waily Torygraph if they'd like me to write something that would get lots of attention, and they said they could do with something like that, and here it is, Marina old girl! If this doesn't get me on top of the news agenda for a solid week then nothing will!   Let me read it to you. I spent five whole minutes on it, it's really good. Listen.  Ahem. If you tell me that we do not have enough state control over what women wear, then I will man the barricades with you, comrades! Let us rip from Muslim women their headscarves, bare the bodies masked by burqas, remark upon the beauty or otherwise of faces covered by niqabs!  It is the sovereign duty of every Englishman, fwar fwar fwar, to see whatever bit of a woman they fancy. Especially if they've got dusky skin. Why, I regularly tell my wife to walk around in a balaclava purely so I can exercise my human right, guaranteed at the signing of Magna Carta, to jump out from behind a tree and rip it off again. And that's why we need to make the Queen walk around naked. Our monarch must set an example that British integration means women being told what to wear, and accepting that most days she looks like a knitted German egg cosy.  I am not in any way being racist. Did I say racist? I didn't mean to. It's what people will call me, of course, racist, but don't let us repeat the word racist in case it causes extra headlines about racism. So many items of female clothing are oppressive, and a truly liberal nation such as ours should not allow women of any race to totter along in high heels, thoughtlessly mimicking the billions of victims of Chinese foot-binding, nor the menace of winter tights that go all bobbly after a single wash and make them look like shabby French mime artists, coming over here and stealing the jobs of Ango-Saxon street artistes.  But let us not stop there, my brethren. Let us also call out the controlling nature of corduroy, the Nazi obsession with nylon, the perverted prevalance of polyester and wrongness of rayon. Nature made totty to titivate us, not to be hidden away! If this makes me a militant feminist then I am happy to confess I am one of the sisterhood.  And don't get me started on people who cover up their God-given bodies for religious reasons. The priesthood attracts paedophiles precisely because their vestments give them the perfect excuse to hide their true natures. And nuns! They're basically just angry penguins, aren't they? Penguins who flatten the wages of British Protestants.   And hair! Women shouldn't be allowed it, for it covers their skulls! Pluck out their eyelashes, epilate their eyebrows, render them clean of fuzz!  Say so long to saris. Wave bye-bye to baggy sweat pants, winter jumpers, 1920s vintage clothing, duffel coats and pyjamas. No woman needs them, and I say so in a spirit of weird and bullying adoration of the female form because otherwise we'll be overrun by half-drowned picaninnies.  In a spirit of gender equality I will also point out that not all men in crash helmets are acid-wielding murderers on a rampage, and of course we should not ban them as that would be an example of nanny state control. But if I make you worry about them, you'll be ripping helmets off little kids on trikes by the end of the week, won't you? Vote for Boris.  The hard truth everyone in this politically-correct world is too frightened to say is that it's simply ridiculous for people to choose to go around looking like letter boxes. Dogs urinating on them! Post being shoved into their cakeholes! Being turned to gold with the curse of King Midas if there's an Olympian nearby! The working classes being oppressed yet again by the elite, of whom I am most definitely one and therefore was born to be PM.    If a woman spoke to me I should feel fully entitled to ask her to divest herself of all clothes first so I could talk to her tits properly. After all, this is how humans have evolved to work. There's no mention of leather jackets in scripture, you know. Off with that woman's head.  It applies also to children with cancer, the malingering little brats, in those hospital gowns they just hide sweets in. Little old ladies in tweed, scarecrows in straw hats, roadworkers lurking behind shapeless hi-vis jackets while treacherously talking this country down. This doesn't mean we should ban clothes or the right of any man or woman to wear what they please when going about their own business. It just means no-one's been talking about Boris since I resigned, apart from the 1,704 mentions I've had since then in British newspapers, and that's not good enough.  So if I say Muslim women look like bank robbers, act all offended when you say I've offended them, and grab lots of headlines while people fail to notice that my 'hard truth' is the same as saying anyone in a mini-skirt is a prostitute , then I'll get away with encouraging millions of people to attack women in the street just to prove they're victims of someone else.  Whaddya think, Marina? Churchillian in its sweep, I think future historians will agree, and so illogical as to take up most of the country's mental bandwidth as they try to understand it and fail to spot that I have become an integral, entertaining and, most worryingly of all, taken-seriously part of their lives. Jolly clever of me, really, ain't it? They'll never notice, and the Tory faithful will lap it up. Next week, I will tell them we need to build a wall on our northern border and make the Scots pay for it, that the NHS must be dismantled for the good of our health and the RAF must shoot down any planes with Muslims on board. We'll call it Boris' Battle of Britain. Rah!

title: man cross referendum bought van
story: NewsThis man was so cross about the referendum he bought a van and is writing 'stop Brexit' all over EuropeAndy Pardy is currently in Norway, drawing the 'P' in 'Stop'.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter17:47, 8 AUG 2018Updated17:48, 8 AUG 2018News (Image: Andy Pardy/therogueconsultant)Get politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A passionate Remainer has quit his job, bought a van and embarked on a three-month mission to write 'stop Brexit ' across Europe.  Andy Pardy, a 28-year-old digital transformation consultant from Exeter, was so upset by the outcome of the referendum he needed a way to vent his frustration. And obviously, what sprang to mind was an epic journey across the continent, using GPS to trace the words on the map. The trip will see him spend around &pound5,000 driving 30,000 miles through 32 countries. The idea came to him, he told the Mirror, when he was out for a run and saw his fitness tracker tracing his route.  Speaking from Norway, where he is about halfway through drawing the 'p' in 'stop', he told the Mirror: I’m trying to embrace one of the privileges we currently have and embark on a farewell tour around Europe. “It covers 32 countries, obviously some of them are non-EU member states. “At the moment I’m in Norway, because I’ve got to see Europe as a canvas. I couldn’t just go to EU member states because I need to have room to draw the message.” He’ll also be visiting Belarus, which is not a member state, because he “needed some space to draw the stem of the ‘p’”  Andy reckons he’s about a quarter of the way in to his odyssey - which will visit every member state except Malta and Cyprus. He says the next leg of his journey will take in Finland and Iceland, before dropping into Estonia. Fittingly, he then plans to draw the word ‘Brexit’ in reverse. Andy isn’t under any illusions that his quest will change the course of history. He said: “I know this won’t stop Brexit, but I just wanted to have my say and make a point.”

title: cyclists branded lycra ws after
story: NewsCyclists branded "Lycra w*****s" after posting video showing motorists' terrible drivingAndy Wallace - who was cycling with pals in the Malvern Hills, Worcestershire - posted the clip to social media where it has caused a very heated debate between cyclists and driversShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCameron Ward13:55, 8 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA group of cyclists have been branded Lycra w*****s after trying to shame motorists for their terrible driving by posting videos online. Andy Wallace posted a clip showing the cycling group being cut up by a van at a junction followed by an overtaking car seconds later, which almost causes a head-on collision. Andy, who was cycling with friends in the Malvern Hills, Worcestershire, posted the clip to social media where it caused a very heated debate between cyclists and drivers. The group were cycling two abreast when the incidents happened and many viewers claimed that was the reason disaster almost struck on Monday afternoon. The video also shows a minivan cutting in front of the group at a junction.  Moments later, a car overtakes the group at high speed despite a vehicle coming in the opposite direction. The overtaking car is forced to swerve back in to avoid a head-on, coming close to hitting the cyclists. But most viewers of the clip, which was posted to a private group, decided Andy and his friends were primarily to blame - and heaped abuse on them. One commenter said: The whole video is full of Lycra clad w*****s thinking they own the road, people like you make me sick. Another said: Cyclist again at fault, b****r off and get a life.  One wrote: Rats of the roads. I give them a good soaking from my window washers whenever I pass these Lycra clad t**s. Yet another wrote: Scourge of the roads...Cyclists - riding in pairs you should get what you deserve. One more considered response stated: No excuse for either of their actions and I'm not condoning it, but you could have prevented the second close call by riding single file and allowing cars to pass. The contributor added: Had there been a single file I bet he would have passed without a problem. Not because the bikes made it easier just because he would have had a different attitude towards the situation. The abuse even strayed on to cyclists and tax with one viewer writing: They don't even pay anything towards the roads' upkeep and they think they own the road. Among those to defend the cyclists, one wrote about riding in pairs: It's not illegal at all. It is deemed safer to ride two abreast, because you can overtake quicker than a long line.  And another defended cyclists from the allegation of tax-dodging. I thought everyone paid taxes, they wrote, unless you're still under the impression you pay 'road tax'. These people are probably saving the country more money than others. Defending cycling as a whole, they added: 1. It's healthy, potentially saving the NHS a lot of money. 2. The wear and tear they do on the roads is considerably less than cars. 3. They aren't spewing out any pollution therefore doing a huge service to the planet. Andy, in his oirignal post, wrote: Two examples of bad driving today. Second one nearly caused a head on crash. Overtaking on top of a small hill. Despite a long straight road just past us.

story: NewsDozy thief caught red-handed trying to sell stolen bike - back to family he pinched it fromSingle mum Jemma Shaw, 29, filmed the thief trying to sell the bike after luring him into her home in Cleethorpes, LincolnshireShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom Kershaw19:05, 8 AUG 2018Updated19:09, 8 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a dozy thief was caught red-handed trying to sell a stolen bike for &pound100 - back to the family he stole it from. The footage was filmed by single-mum Jemma Shaw, 29, who lured the thief in to her home after offering to buy the bike less than 24 hours after it was taken. Jemma's 12-year-old son Alfie Whitby had his beloved BMX stolen from a park close to their home in Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire on Sunday. Mum-of-two Jemma scoured Facebook and saw the thief had listed the item for sale on a local selling site so contacted the seller to see if she could have a look at it. The hapless thief can be heard on the video saying 'I've had it for ages' after being challenged by Jemma about where he got the bike from.  He is seen trudging into Jemma's front room with the bike and she challenges him: No you haven't, you stole this yesterday, you're on video. The thief, who was sporting a South Park t-shirt, then huffs 'errr, ok then' and then makes a run for it out the front door. Jemma then shouts after him: You have stolen from a 12-year-old boy - you absolute evil b*****d. But it wasn't all bad news for Jemma and Alfie - who bought the bike for &pound160 new - as the thief had even fixed his broken back brake.  Jemma, who has lived at the address for a year and owns her own cleaning business, said: Over the past year I have become a very spiritual person. I now see the good in everyone. I don't believe we should be scared of people like this or be worried about things happening in the places where they live.

title: half single 40 somethings regularly
story: NewsHalf of single 40-somethings regularly having unprotected sexBrits are ignoring the risks of catching sexually transmitted infections, study foundShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAstrid Hall16:05, 8 AUG 2018News (Image: Getty)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Nearly half of single 40-somethings are regularly having unprotected sex , it has emerged.  Researchers who carried out a detailed study into middle aged dating found a large percentage of older Brits are ignoring the risks of catching sexually transmitted infections and having sex without a condom. And that has lead to two in every 100 discovering they have contracted an STI since turning 40, according to the report. One third said they ignore contraception because they no longer worry about pregnancy. But this comes despite three in 100 having an unplanned pregnancy over 40, and fertility rates for women over 40 now exceeding that of women under 20. Other reasons for unprotected sex are that a quarter are using other methods of contraception, despite these not protecting against STIs. The study also found 36 per cent of men and 24 per cent of women have had a sexual encounter blighted by erectile dysfunction. And one in four believe impotence makes dating more difficult for older people. Jane Devenish, pharmacist at Well Pharmacy, which commissioned the research among 2,000 over 40s, said: “Practicing safe sex is just as important for people over 40 as it is for younger people. ''And with evidence that STIs are on the increase in the UK, we would advise people actively dating at any age to use condoms to protect themselves against STIs and unplanned pregnancies.  The research also revealed some major barriers to finding love over 40, with lack of body confidence, family baggage, health conditions, and erectile dysfunction coming out on top. Jane added: “Our research revealed the serious impact erectile dysfunction can have, with 42 per cent of people in relationships having less or no sex with their partner. Forty per cent of singles admitted it made them feel anxious about having sex, and 25 per cent had less body confidence as a result of the experience. More than two thirds of adults over 40 believed impotence is caused by stress or anxiety, with an equal number pinning the blame on drinking too much alcohol. More than half reckoned it’s the side effect of taking medication and 44 per cent said it’s a result of old age. Jane explains: “Contrary to popular belief, old age does not cause impotence. Many men experience occasions when they struggle to get or maintain an erection, and this is usually due to stress, tiredness or drinking too much, and is nothing to worry about. ''However, if erection problems keep on happening, it could be a sign of an underlying health condition such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol or even diabetes.

title: married downs syndrome couple choose
story: NewsMarried Down's syndrome couple choose 23rd anniversary cards for each other - only to get heartwarming surpriseMaryanne and Tommy Pilling, who tied the knot in a beautiful church ceremony in 1995, proved how well they know each other with their choice of cardsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans12:53, 8 AUG 2018Updated12:55, 8 AUG 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter more than two decades of wedded bliss and countless special moments, it's safe to say most couples know each other inside out.  And Maryanne, 46, and Tommy Pilling, 60, are no different - as they recently proved with their choice of anniversary cards for each other.  The happy couple, who both have Down's syndrome, celebrated an incredible 23 years of marriage last month with their loved ones.  But when they handed each other the cards they had lovingly chosen, they were met with a heartwarming surprise - because they matched.  Maryanne's card for her doting partner was a light green-blue colour, with the words: For my amazing HUSBAND on our anniversary.   And the one she received back was almost identical - but in a light pink colour and reading: For my beautiful WIFE on our anniversary.  Remarkably, the cards both had the same design.  The couple's stunned loved ones shared an image of the cards on a Facebook page which follows Maryanne and Tommy's romance. They wrote: The anniversary cards that Maryanne and Tom bought for each other..... I never realised they knew each other quite so well!! Maryanne and Tommy, who live together in Southend-on-Sea, Essex, tied the knot in a beautiful church ceremony in July 1995. The beaming bride wore a Cinderella-style gown for the Shoeburyness service, while her groom donned a made-to-measure suit.  Almost a quarter of a century on, they remain happily married, sharing kisses and cuddles and making amazing memories every day. Maryanne tells her husband she loves him three times a day, lights up when she speaks of him and enjoys going out to concerts with him.  But sadly, in recent years, Tommy has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease - and continues to display early signs of the condition.  He is getting more forgetful, while it is becoming harder for him to speak and be understood by those who aren't close to him. Maryanne's mum Linda Martin explained what she and other loved ones have told her daughter about Tommy's condition and the future. At the moment, we just say that Tommy is getting older and he forgets things, and he needs a bit more care, she said in a recent podcast.  And that is enough for Maryanne to deal with at the moment. We go on a day -to-day basis. So at this moment, baby steps, she added. Linda spoke out about her daughter and son-in-law on Jo Piazza's Committed Podcast earlier this year, ahead of their anniversary.  She also revealed her joy at the couple's beautiful love for each other.  This love has defied both the odds and critics - who have previously called Linda a 'bad mother' for allowing Maryanne to get married. But as far as the mum is concerned, the fact her daughter has found somebody to love is the best thing she could have ever wished for. She said: I wish I could have found a love like it in my life - because it's very honest, it's very true and it really is a beautiful thing.  She added: I can always remember saying I don't care what she [Maryanne] achieves, I just hope to God she finds somebody to love. And she did, she has. And to me, that's the best thing I could have ever wished for her. Maryanne and Tommy's fairytale relationship began 28 years ago. The couple, who share a passion for cooking, met through fate in 1990 while working in a local training centre for people with disabilities. At the time, Maryanne was 19 - 13 years younger than Tommy. But from the moment they met, they shared an incredible connection. When asked what she thought of her first encounter with her future husband, Maryanne told podcast host Jo: That I love him. Just true love. It wasn't long after that Maryanne brought Tommy home to meet her family. She giggled happily as she proudly introduced him.  That's when I realised my little girl was falling in love, said Linda. Although Tommy was fairly quiet, Maryanne soon brought him out of his shell. And a year after they met, things became very serious. Deciding he wished to propose to his beloved girlfriend, a besotted Tommy bought a plastic ring for her from a vending machine. He then gave it to Maryanne, who was elated. She excitedly showed her mum the ring, saying Tommy wants us to get engaged. Linda, who admitted her first thought was good God, sat down with her daughter and Tommy and asked them what they wanted. In response, the couple said they wished to marry each other.  Linda then took the pair to get a proper ring and for the next four years, they remained engaged, getting to know each other properly. In mid-July 1995, they finally tied the knot in a perfect' ceremony, surrounded by hundreds of family and friends, and so much love. Linda said her daughter looked stunning in her white dress, tiara and long veil, while Tommy proudly wore his made-to-measure suit. For their honeymoon, the couple stayed in a seafront hotel, according to the podcast, 'Love Me Tender', which was released earlier this summer. Afterwards, Tommy moved into Maryanne’s family home. However, amid the post-wedding bliss, Linda received cruel messages telling her that she shouldn't have allowed her daughter to get married. But she told Jo: For me as a mother, I would have felt I'd failed her if I hadn't acknowledged the fact that she was in love with somebody.  Maryanne and Tommy later moved into their own flat. Today, they continue to live independently there, next door to both of their mums and across the road from Maryanne's sister, Lindi. And despite needing assistance from their loved ones with most aspects of their life, including cooking and washing, they manage superbly. They go out on dates and day trips and, recently, Tommy celebrated his 60th birthday with a huge party. As always, his wife was by his side. Pictures of the happy pair - who were thought to be the first couple with Down's syndrome to wed in 1995 - are regularly posted online.  The Facebook page about their relationship - set up by Lindi - has amassed more than 40,000 followers, with the numbers rising.   A post on the 'Maryanne and Tommy' page reveals the couple renewed their wedding vows 13 years ago - then again three years ago. It adds: They have now been together for 28 years, since Maryanne was 19 years of age. Tommy is 13 years older than Maryanne and he recently celebrated turning 60! On World Down Syndrome day too! Their marriage is like a fairytale and they are the most blissfully happy couple that I know. I think most of us could learn a thing or two from them! When they got engaged 25 years ago many many people doubted them, said it was disgusting and they shouldn’t be allowed to get married, they also said that it would never work. But I like to say they are still as happy as they were 28 years ago when they first met. This page shows their love for one another quite clearly, it shows how happy they are, how much they adore each other and it proves to all the doubters that anything is possible with love.

title: mum boy 6 left vomiting
story: NewsMum of boy, 6, left vomiting in A&E for 11 HOURS claims he was 'forgotten about'Lisa Roberts has described her son's ordeal as "absolutely disgraceful" - but the hospital has since apologised and said it was a “particularly challenging weekend”Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKelly Williams15:20, 8 AUG 2018NewsHe arrived at hospital at 10am but didn't leave until 1am the next day (Image: UGC TNW)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mum of a six-year-old boy left vomiting in A&ampE for 11 hours claims they were forgotten about and even 'drunks' were seen before her sick son. Lisa Roberts says she cannot understand why Nigel Roberts Jnr was not at least given an anti-sickness tablet to ease the suffering after he was taken to hospital with stomach pains. They arrived by ambulance at around 10am on Sunday but were not sent home until 1am the following day. And despite, throwing up 18 times, Mrs Roberts says her son was forced to wait hours to be transferred to the paediatric ward, and only then was he given a pill. Ysbyty Glan Clwyd hospital admitted staff were under pressure due to a “particularly challenging weekend” with an “exceptionally high level” of ambulances arriving at the site in Wales.   Mrs Roberts told the Daily Post : “Nigel had really bad pains in his stomach and wasn’t able to keep any food or liquids down.  “We called 999 for an ambulance and got to hospital at 10am where we waited in A&ampE for 30 minutes before he was seen by a triage nurse. “We were taken through into another waiting room and were left in there for four hours. “A nurse came and told us that the wait would be another two hours. Meanwhile, Nigel was constantly being sick and crying with pain. “He was eventually seen by a doctor at 5pm, who said he either had a bug or a viral infection.  “We were sent back to the waiting room until 9.30pm when the doctor said she needed a urine sample from Nigel. “It was 10.45pm when he was sent up to the paediatric department.” Mrs Roberts said Nigel was seen straight away once he got to paediatrics and was given an anti-sickness pill. “I don’t understand why the doctor in A&ampE couldn’t have given it to him instead of leaving him being sick for all those hours, it’s absolutely disgraceful,” she added. “We counted he was sick 18 times while he was there.  “It wasn’t until 12.30am that he managed to eat some toast and we were allowed to go home at 1am on Monday. “It’s like we were forgotten about – meanwhile, the police were in and out bringing drunk people in. It was like being in a third-rate country.” A spokesperson for Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board said: “Due to patient confidentiality we are unable to comment on individual cases, however we would like to offer our sincere apologies to Mrs Roberts for the delay experienced while waiting for treatment for her son Nigel. “We’re very sorry to hear that Mrs Roberts is unhappy with the care her son received and we would encourage the family to contact us directly with any concerns. “It was a particularly challenging weekend at Glan Clwyd Hospital with an exceptionally high level of ambulances arriving at the hospital site.

title: prince harry left more money
story: NewsWhy Prince Harry was left more money from the Queen Mother than big brother WilliamPrince Harry and his brother William were reportedly left more than £14m by their great-grandmother, but the younger was given a much bigger chunkShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor15:39, 8 AUG 2018Updated19:20, 8 AUG 2018NewsThe Queen Mother at her 99th birthday celebrations with Princes Harry, William, and Charles (Image: UK Press)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrinces William and Harry are, well, princes, so they're not exactly short of a few bob. Their money comes from a number of different sources, and they've both had paid jobs in the past. But a lot of their fortune is from inheritance, with their mum Diana and their great-grandmother leaving them money in their wills. While Diana's fortune was split evenly between them, Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother decided to leave Prince Harry a lot more than his older brother.  But it wasn't just because she preferred Harry or had some strange problem with William, and there was actually a very thoughtful reason behind it. Years before she died, the Queen Mother reportedly put a large chunk of her money into a trust fund for all her great grandchildren. Harry and William shared about &pound14m of this, with the bulk going to Harry, reports the BBC . When the Queen dies and Prince Charles becomes king, the Duke of Cambridge, Prince William, will become the new Prince of Wales. This means he will take on the Duchy of Cornwall, a private estate which funds the public, charitable and private activities of the heir to the throne. Prince Harry on the other hand, won't get any of this.  After her death, Buckingham Palace released an outline of the Queen Mother's will, after going through the high court to try and keep it private. Her estate, which was valued at between &pound50m and &pound70m at the time, was passed onto her daughter the Queen. Her majesty did not have to pay inheritance on the fortune. Many items from the Queen's private art collection were given to the royal collection and went on display at the Palace. Prince Charles moved into her home Clarence House. A statement released at the time read: Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother has bequeathed her entire estate (which mainly comprises the contents of her houses) to The Queen.

title: ryanair strike airline cancels 250
story: NewsRyanair strike: Airline cancels 250 MORE flights giving 45,000 passengers just 48 hours' noticeEurope's biggest budget airline said it had informed passengers affected by the cancellations and offered them a refund or another routeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth14:48, 8 AUG 2018Updated19:07, 8 AUG 2018NewsRyanair airplanes stand idle on the tarmac during the first day of strike (Image: REX/Shutterstock)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRyanair has suddenly cancelled hundreds more flights this week because of a strike by pilots, with thousands of passengers affected. The airline said it had notified fliers affected by the cancellation of 250 flights on Friday, offering them a refund or another route. Ryanair pilots in Sweden, Belgium and Ireland had already voted to stage a 24-hour strike that day, leading to the cancellation of 22 flights for Sweden, 104 for Belgium, and 20 for Ireland. All affected customers have already been contacted. Pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) announced that Ryanair pilots in Germany will also be striking on Friday over pay and conditions.  Around 45,000 passengers were to be given 48 hours’ notice or less that their flights had been cancelled, according to the Independent. The airline said the strike in Germany was unjustified and apologised to customers for the regrettable disruption. It added that it had been forced to cancel 250 flights of over 2,400 flights scheduled to operate on Friday. Ryanair's Kenny Jacobs said: We regret the decision of the VC to go ahead with this unnecessary strike action given that we sent through a revised proposal on a Collective Labour Agreement (CLA) and stated our intention to work towards achieving a CLA together. We also invited VC to meet us on Tuesday but they did not respond to this invitation.  Our pilots in Germany enjoy excellent working conditions. They are paid up to E190,000 a year and, as well as additional benefits, they received a 20 per cent pay increase at the start of this year. Ryanair pilots earn at least 30 per cent more than Eurowings and 20 per cent more than Norwegian pilots.  We asked VC to provide us with at least seven days' notice of any planned strike action so that we could notify our customers of cancelled flights in advance and offer them alternative flights or refunds, but they have refused to do this and instead call an unnecessary strike in Germany in just two days' time. Ryanair is ready to continue these negotiations.

title: schoolgirl footballer left unable walk
story: NewsSchoolgirl footballer left unable to walk after 'small bump on head' triggers devastating illnessWithin 12 hours Jade Almond, 16, the Wigan Athletic Ladies goalkeeper, began suffering 'multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's-like symptoms'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByTom Kershaw19:28, 8 AUG 2018NewsSoccer-mad Jade Almond, 16, accidentally banged her head on a door frame at school after leaning back too far on her chair three weeks ago (Image: SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA talented teenage goalkeeper has been left with severe shakes and unable to walk properly after bumping her head at school trigged a serious condition. Soccer-mad Jade Almond, 16, hit her head on a door frame after leaning back too far on her chair three weeks ago. Within 12 hours the budding goalie was left with uncontrollable shakes and unable to put her pressure on her right leg. The condition has left her right leg 'shivering constantly' with extreme shaking 'like she was wearing a bikini in the Antarctic'. Doctors have now said the bump triggered a mystery condition called functional neurological disorder (FND).  The Wigan Athletic Ladies goalie is suffering multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease-like symptoms and will need to undertake a strict rehabilitation regime in order to recover. Jade's anxious mother Michelle Almond, 41, says the teenage goalkeeping starlet had her whole life ahead of her before the bizarre injury. Michelle, of Wigan, Lancs., said: Jade is a trooper and doing really well - she had the whole world ahead of her and now this has happened. Jade was undertaking a four week long National Citizen Service (NCS) course, an annual school holiday scheme set up brimming with activities, which included rafting and climbing in the first week. But it was in the classroom in week two of the four week task at the University of Manchester when she hit her head on the back of a door frame on Saturday, July 14. It left the football mad teen feeling sick and 'spaced out' but she continued with her pals and partook in the afternoon session. However, Jade then hit her head again on the window of their mini bus, due to the motion of the vehicle, while travelling to another part of the campus.  Jade said: I can't remember much of the day after hitting my head on the door frame. It's all a blur really to be honest, I was just out of it. All I want to do now is to get better, be able to go to Sixth Form in September and continue doing what I was doing. After becoming ill and not being able to walk at 9pm the same evening, she was sent to Manchester Royal Infirmary by worried course organisers. I got the dreaded call from the organisers of the award who said Jade had bumped her head and was being sent to hospital, said call handler Michelle. The mum-of-three added: Jade being a goalkeeper, we knew it was bad because she is a tough goalkeeper. She's had broken bones and cuts and bruises - she's tough. She has never suffered from headaches or have any family members who have neurological diseases. Jade just shakes and to look at her you would think she has Parkinson's - it's that bad. It's like she is wearing a bikini in the Antarctic and is just shivering constantly on her right leg.

title: stay home mum earns 70k
story: NewsStay-at-home mum earns £70k a year working just two hours a day selling unwanted Louboutin heelsCharlotte Jones, 30, started her business after she wore her beloved Christian Louboutin shoes into the groundShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByEmily Hall12:49, 8 AUG 2018Updated19:04, 8 AUG 2018NewsCharlotte Jones says her motto is work smart, not hard (Image: Triangle News)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum says she's turned passion for designer Louboutin heels into a &pound70,000-a-year business - and she only works two hours a day.   Charlotte Jones fell in love with the luxury shoe brand - worn by celebrities including Kate Moss, Beyonce and Melania Trump - when her partner gave her a pair as a gift.  The 30-year-old wore the black heels into the ground and, after booking a holiday to Ibiza three years ago, she realised they were so battered she needed new ones. But she didn't want to pay &pound800 and feared she would end up with fakes if she bought them online.  It was then that Charlotte got the idea to set up her own shoe salon specialising in unworn and unwanted Loubs at a fraction of the cost. She spent a year learning how to properly authenticate the shoes named after high end French stiletto creator Christian Louboutin, who has been designing women's heels since 1991. Charlotte now runs her own brand Love Luxe from her home in Barnsley, South Yorks.  Her earnings now trump her partner Dael Baxter, 33, an internet marketer who helped her set up the business officially last year. It means she can stay home with stepson Jack, 11, and daughters Anyssa, seven, and Briseis, three months. Charlotte said she has sold upwards of 400 pairs of Louboutins and celebrity fans include glamour model Chloe Khan and reality star Jodie Marsh. She also sells other high end designer gear like Chanel and Alexander McQueen.  But her real passion is still Louboutins. She now has a network of private sellers, many with collections in the hundreds. Most of the shoes she sells are boxed and unworn, with their owners being given so many pairs by partners and husbands that they simply can't wear them all. Charlotte said: It's hard to believe, but there are ladies out there with hundreds of pairs and many of them aren't even fussed. It started by chance really. About three years ago, I only had one pair of Louboutins and I'd worn them to death.  Me and my partner had a nice holiday planned, we were going to Ibiza and planned to try out some really nice restaurants and I wanted to look good. Obviously I needed some new shoes but I didn't want to buy two or three pairs of Louboutins at full price because they're so expensive. I was looking around and realised that there wasn't really anything in between. You can either buy them full price or you can chance it [online] ... but you never really know whether they're authentic.  I contacted some private sellers and managed to get two or three pairs at less than half the price. I just thought 'There's a market for this'. It started as a hobby and then just snowballed. Part of the job is driving hundreds of miles to pick up pairs from across the country and her car is often crammed full of Louboutin cardboard boxes. As well as selling the brand, she also has her own collection of 11 pairs - including her first ever &pound495 Irizas - but says her tastes are always evolving. Her aim was to allow women just like her the opportunity to be able to afford a pair of designer shoes without having to fork out for the huge price tag, which for many was unaffordable.  She even offers prospective purchasers credit if they need it as well as a 14-day return window. Charlotte said: A lot of the shoes are brand new, the ladies have been bought them as gifts and they don't fit or they don't like them. You'd be amazed, some women have huge collections and they never wear them. Every lady should be able to buy a pair of high end shoes. She added: I don't make too much of a profit. I try and keep the price as low as possible.

title: heroic groom stopped wedding photos
story: NewsHeroic groom stopped his wedding photos to dive into the ocean and save teenager from drowningZac Edwards risked his own life on his wedding day to save the life of an 18-year-old manShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly09:49, 8 AUG 2018Updated11:18, 8 AUG 2018NewsThe couple were posing on Orange Beach when the drama unfolded (Image: Beach Dream Weddings / SWNS)Get daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A brave groom interrupted his own wedding photos to dive into the ocean and stop a teenager from drowning.  Zac Edwards, 37, was posing for pictures with bride Cindy Edwards, 32, on Friday when panicked guests spotted the teenager struggling in the water. The marine science technician immediately plunged into the water and swam 150 feet to help the boy. He had got into difficulty in strong currents while playing on a boogie board at Shell Beach in Gulf State Park in Alabama.  Zac propped the youngster on the boogie board and arrived at his own wedding reception soaked and covered in sand.   You could just tell by the look on his face he was in difficulty. When we first saw him he was about 50 yards out. I took off my shirt, but my wife said I didn't have time to take off my pants. I ran into the water. I told some kids to go back to the beach and I took a boogie board. I’m so glad I did that, Zac said. The newly wed, of Spanish Fort, Alabama, added: I eventually reached him but we were about half a football field away from the shore. He just kept saying 'I can’t breathe'. I tried to keep his head above water and I propped him up onto the boogie board.  The current was really strong and it was stopping us coming in any further. I was starting to panic slightly. The pants were making it hard to kick too. But when I saw the first responders I knew it was going to be okay. A jet ski came out to us and I managed to wedge him up onto it. I didn’t really take in the gravity of the situation until I laid down that night. Afterwards my hands were shaking but the adrenaline was just pumping. Orange Beach Fire Department and Orange Beach Surf Rescue, who had been attending to another emergency on the beach, assisted the marine expert and wedged the teenager onto a jetski. Zac jumped on himself and returned the lad to shore. Cindy, who had been with Zac for one year before tying the knot, admitted she panicked her husband was tiring during the dramatic rescue.  She said: I could tell Zac was tiring and they couldn’t get over the current. They had stopped and I was worried. Thank God the first responders arrived. The lifeguards dived into the water and there were helicopters were patrolling the waters. Our emergency services in Orange Beach can’t be commended enough. Luckily, the teenager has since recovered. Now Cindy and Zac, who each have three children, have warned of the importance of water safety.
